Therefore, does the minister concede that the issue of indigenous sovereignty remains unresolved, that the promise of a previous Prime Minister to enter into a treaty or series of treaties remains unhonoured and that to proceed to alter the fundamental rights of indigenous people with these issues outstanding is entirely wrong? Also, is any minister of this government intending to visit the people at the tent embassy to explain your views to them?

—During the recent Constitutional Convention, at a quiet moment I happened to listen to an address outside the tent embassy where this argument was being put. But I think the bottom line is in fact that what the government is seeking to do is find a fair and just solution to a range of problems—problems in terms of their practical sense—that arise from the law as it has been promulgated by the courts in recent times. There is no doubt that, in seeking to implement the court's ruling in relation to native title, there are a whole range of practical issues that need to be addressed. They have been addressed by the parliament in order that we can provide reasonable certainty that is consistent with the rights that the High Court has told us exist. That is the way this government is addressing this particular difficult issue and I think, in all circumstances, it is the proper way to act. (Time expired)

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, given that the Prime Minister's code of conduct says, `Ministers are required to divest themselves of all shares and similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of their portfolio responsibilities,' on what basis did Mr Max Moore-Wilton advise the Prime Minister's office that Senator Parer was not in breach of the code? Did Mr Max Moore-Wilton make this judgment on the basis of his personal and extensive experience in the share market?

—I think Senator Faulkner should start with the unwritten code of conduct, which basically says, `If you defame innocent individuals, whether they be alive or dead, you should at least have the decency to come in here and apologise.' It is not a big thing to do. It is not all that hard. All you have to do is get up here and say, `I made a mistake and I'm sorry. I'm sorry that I defamed the Baillieus.' When you apologise—
—Tell us about Moore-Wilton. I know you are a rorter. Tell us about Max Moore-Wilton.

—You did not have the nerve. You did not do what Senator Ray said and take 15 steps to courage. You would not say it outside because you knew you had defamed them. You would not say it outside. You know you have defamed them and you know you have got it totally wrong. But you have not got the decency to stand here in this place and say you are sorry. It is not a difficult thing to do.
—I know you are a rorter. I asked a question about your rorts.
—No. We are not talking about me.
—Order! Senator Hill has the call. Any other senator speaking at the time is in breach of the standing orders. I ask you to note that.
—He is required to answer the question.
—Under which standing order is he required to answer the question?

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. My point of order is on the basis of relevance. As you would be aware, Madam President, ministers are required—and normally presidents direct them—to answer questions that are directed to them by any senator in the chamber. I ask you to draw to the minister's attention the fact that he is not answering a very direct question that has been directed to him.

—There is no point of order. There is no standing order which requires that and there has never been. Senator Hill has been asked a question about standards and behaviour. He is answering it as he sees fit.

—The point is, Madam President, that the question was premised by Senator Faulkner talking about a code of conduct, standards of behaviour, and that is the way I am answering it—standards of behaviour that he expects of ministers, standards of behaviour that we expect of all parliamentarians. When they stand in the coward's castle and defame innocent bystanders, they should at least have the decency to come in here and say they were wrong and apologise. When Senator Faulkner does that, he will be better placed to come in here and ask about questions relating to the conduct of ministers. As Senator Faulkner knows, the Prime Minister has said that he is totally satisfied that Senator Parer has complied with the ministerial code of conduct and I have no intention of second-guessing the Prime Minister on that matter.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I did ask the minister on what basis Mr Max Moore-Wilton advised the Prime Minister's office that Senator Parer was not in breach of the code. I would appreciate an answer. I understand, of course, that Senator Parer's declaration to the Prime Minister was referred to Mr Max Moore-Wilton for checking on 7 May 1997. Was this, Minister, the same time at which Dr Shergold was conducting his own inquiry into Mr Moore-Wilton's use of entitlements? Also, what value would the Prime Minister attach to an all-clear from Mr Max Moore-Wilton in these circumstances?

—That is just about as grubby as they get; certainly as grubby as anything I have heard in here in 16 years. It all seems to be part of a consistent pattern: just lash out; throw the bit of muck around; do it often enough and with a bit of luck just a little bit will stick ultimately. You have a go at Senator Parer; you now have a go at a senior public servant; you basically had a go at the Baillieus. The Baillieus are not even in the business, but you have a go at them.

answer.para: The point that Senator Faulkner does not seem to appreciate is that it is for the Prime Minister to decide whether the standards he set are being met. He has so decided, and that is the end of the matter.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Will the minister inform the Senate of the seriousness with which the government regards the chase for Mr Christopher Skase and his assets? There have been suggestions that the chase for Skase is a waste of taxpayers' money. What is the minister's response to these suggestions?

—I thank Senator Coonan for the question. The government, as opposed to the opposition, clearly takes the chase for Skase and his assets seriously. We know quite clearly that the government takes it more seriously than the opposition, because if they did take it seriously—it having been shown that their shadow Attorney-General had leaked highly confidential Federal Court documents that had the potential to damage and make more difficult that pursuit—Mr Beazley would have shown some courage, demanded standards be set by his alternative first law officer and would have sacked Senator Bolkus.

answer.para: Senator Bolkus would be in here today, rather than wherever he is. He accuses this place of being a kangaroo court. It begs the question whether you have sent him some sort of community service order and that is why he is not here. But if you have, and he is out planting some plants somewhere, I will give you a tip—count the seedlings. I would count the seedlings.

The government does take this seriously. Fugitives cannot be allowed to escape from justice and a blind eye turned. It is same with criminal law and corporations law as it is with standards in this place. You have to set an example. When you turn a blind eye to the wrong thing being done, you set a new low standard. That is what Mr Beazley is doing by failing to sack Senator Bolkus.

This place is not a kangaroo court. It is a sort of two-fingered salute to the Greens, the Democrats, Senator Harradine and senators on this side. Madam President, every senator in this place who is not a Labor senator voted to condemn Senator Bolkus for what he did. Nonetheless, he still says it is a kangaroo court and he does not care. He has no standards; the Leader of the Opposition has no standards; Senator Faulkner has no standards. If they were prepared to sack Senator Bolkus, we could say that they had some.

But you only have to look at the past to see what sorts of standards the Australian public can expect from the opposition. The sorts of standards that they got in government were the sorts of standards that, I am advised, meant that Prime Minister Keating in 1988 failed to reveal to cabinet his relationship with Warren Anderson at a time when cabinet was deciding to allow the Northern Territory to expand its debt to build a new $130 million state square project in Darwin. And who was to be the developer? The developer was to be Warren Anderson. In 1992 Senator Richardson continued to be a director of 2HD when he was Minister for Transport and Communications. They are some examples of the sorts of standards that were set by Labor when they were in government.

What we have seen over the last few days is in direct contrast to the standards that we want to uphold and the Democrats want to uphold. Even the Greens voted with us yesterday to indicate that this was an unsatisfactory standard by Senator Bolkus. It was an historic censure, because I do not think it has not happened in living memory—and perhaps because the Greens voted with us.

There are plenty of other examples of the sorts of standards that Labor is prepared to accept in this place. Senator Faulkner defamed dead men as part of a Baillieu rort and failed to apologise. He claimed that someone was chairman of a company when they had resigned three years earlier. Senator Sherry, who sits at the back of the chamber, had a go at Dr Lyle Williams and failed to apologise for what he did—just come in here, smear anybody, put it on the record and don't worry about it. Senator Sherry came in here and cast stones and he should be prepared to apologise when he has got it wrong. We saw Senator O'Brien—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has indicated that the government does take seriously the pursuit of Mr Skase. Will the minister further detail how the government's stand in upholding Australia's bankruptcy laws is being upheld?

—Yes, the government does take it seriously. We believe that by supporting Mr Donnelly in his chase for assets we are demonstrating to anybody else who wants to do the same as Mr Skase did, that it is unacceptable. It is an unacceptable standard and we will pursue them. This government is about setting standards; standards that we do not see from the opposition.

answer.para: I was about to say that Senator O'Brien had alleged that Allhands Hire was a business that was put up for sale. Yesterday Senator Ellison came into this place, indicated it was not for sale and the company had consequently lost a number of clients. Senator Quirke suggested a gold shovel had been bought and there was some sort of sleazy deal for Burson Marsteller, only to find that it was Labor who in fact gave that contract out. In stark contrast to the standards that are not permitted here, this government will implement standards. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, is it not the case that your shares in Queensland Coal Mine Management have experienced remarkable capital growth in recent years, with the value of the company assets growing from $15.9 million in 1995 to $153 million in 1996? Is it not also the case that both you and the Prime Minister claimed in parliament last night that there was `just no scope for public divestment' of those shares? Do you and the Prime Minister stand by that statement?
—Yes—public divesture, yes. These shares are 16 non-voting shares in the company. What I talked about was public divestment, divestment—

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There is far too much noise. Senator Parer is entitled to silence while he answers a question and should not be interrupted by all sides of the chamber.

—What the Prime Minister said, and I think what I said too, was that it is the disbursement of those shares as compared with publicly listed shares. There is not an open market out there. I have no idea what they are worth.

answer.para: Let me get back to the point. Senator Cook is hammering away about dividends that come from an investment by a family trust in another company. What we are on about—and this is what I thought Senator Ray and others were on about when they got up—is saying, `Let's look at the registration of interests, whether it be the Senate or the Prime Minister's guidelines, and see whether there is a conflict of interest.' If anyone thinks—and I say this again and again and again—that in the office that I hold and in the two years I have held it there has ever been a perception of a conflict of interest in respect of me or even my family's trust, let them get up and say it. This fishing around is stupid. Just give me one example, Senator Ray.

talk.start.para: —It is perception, not reality.
—There has been no conflict of interest and there has been no perception of interest.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, that is an interesting answer. Is it not true that the only prohibition on selling shares in Queensland Coal Mine Management is that prior consent of just three ordinary shareholders must be obtained? Did you make any effort to obtain such consent? If not, why did you not?

—I think I have answered this very clearly. I have answered this in the answers I gave yesterday and in the explanation I gave last night and today. There is nothing more I can add to what I have said.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer), to questions without notice asked today, relating to the financial interests of Senator Parer.

Despite what is overwhelming evidence to the contrary, Senator Parer is proclaiming that he is not guilty of any conflict of interest nor any other sackable offence. But I think it is worth examining closely these protestations of innocence from Senator Parer. Firstly, let us look at the issue of the Senate's requirements in relation to its system of disclosure of pecuniary interests. Senator Parer has failed to declare to the Registrar of Senators' Interests his directorship of Investment Management Pty Ltd, his family trust company. He has failed to declare his shareholding in that company or his family trust shareholdings.

Senator Parer claims not to be aware of the letter of 20 March 1997 from the Registrar of Senators' Interests informing all senators of the requirements to `notify actual shares held by relevant family or business trusts as of 20 March 1997'. He claims to be only in technical breach of the guidelines. But he conveniently fails to mention the fact—he ignores the fact—that he has also failed to declare his shareholding in Queensland Coal Management ESP. This was a requirement of the Senate disclosure system from the very beginning. It is not a technical breach; it is a serious breach.

Then there is the issue of compliance with the code of conduct of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). That is now an infamous and much discredited document. Surely we need to go no further than the requirement on page 11 of this code, which says:

Ministers are required to divest themselves of all shares and similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of their portfolio responsibilities. The transfer of interests to a family member or to a nominee or trust is not an acceptable form of divestment.

Does Senator Parer possess shares or similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of his portfolio responsibilities? The answer to that question is yes, he does. Has Senator Parer divested himself of these shares and interests? The answer is, of course, that he has not. Is he in compliance with this much discredited prime ministerial code of conduct? No, he is not. Of course, you could look, in relation to ministerial conduct, at page 10 of the code:

The nature of their duties is such that they may need to have regard to the interests of members of their immediate families (to the extent that ministers know their interests) as well as their own when ensuring that no conflict or apparent conflict between interests and duties arises.

Again, the same problems. But what the opposition in the Senate has been asking today is: what about his compliance with the Prime Minister's requirements for a confidential declaration of interests from all his ministers?

Here we only have Senator Parer's word. Why should we accept it? He would not answer direct questions from Senator Cook which were directed to him in question time today on a range of issues in relation to disclosures he made to the Prime Minister. He insists that he fully complied with the Prime Minister's requirements. We invite him to table confidential documentation in the Senate to prove that that is the case.

The truth is that on those three grounds—the Senate requirements, the ministerial code of conduct and the Prime Minister's confidential declaration; on all three counts—Senator Parer has failed. He is a liability to the government. Our view is that there is no alternative for him but to resign or be sacked by the Prime Minister. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am not going to give respectability to a perfectly scurrilous attack on the charac ter of one of the best senators in this place. I have known Senator Parer longer than anyone in this parliament. I knew him many years before he came in here 12 years ago. Senator Parer's integrity, his honesty and his probity is beyond dispute in any way at all; way beyond challenge. He is a fit and proper person to discharge the duties of a minister in this place. That ought to be the end of the argument.

—We have just heard from Senator MacGibbon on this. Senator MacGibbon, the Prime Minister marched into the House of Representatives, puffed up, in May 1996 and said, `I'm setting a whole new standard.' He implicitly criticised the previous government, even though a lot was drawn from the cabinet handbook. We are simply asking that Senator Parer and every other minister observe those standards.

speech.para: There is no use saying that we are being scurrilous in this. The first question we raised was: why didn't Senator Parer comply with the March 1997 directive from the registrar? What is his response to that, Senator MacGibbon? `I'm guilty,' he says. We have established that. It is not a completely threadbare assault on Senator Parer. Then we asked the second question: why didn't you declare your 44 shares which were declarable long before the March 1997 directive? We did not really get an explanation as to why they were not declared. We asked him whether he declared them to the Prime Minister. Through all the fog of the answer I got the impression that he did not. Then we hear the Prime Minister over there in the other place absolutely asserting that he was notified of the 44 shares. We need to clear that up.

The one thing that is difficult for Senator MacGibbon or anyone else to argue about is the clear reference in the ministerial code of conduct to disposing of shares which directly affect your portfolio area. He did not do that. They were not easy to dispose of—we can see that. But if he had let us know that he had them and that he had difficulty in disposing of them we would have some idea that there was a potential or a perceived conflict of interest.

Senator Parer jumped on the point I made yesterday. I will repeat it for him if he wants to jump on it every time and grab it like a lifeline. I do not think Senator Parer would ever deliberately go out and enrich himself in this area by an action to favour a particular company where he has an investment. But neither will I accuse Senator Short or Senator Gibson of that. They breached the ministerial code. They went; Senator Parer does not go.

The other side gets upset when we question the basis of these financial arrangements. But he was someone, absent from a meeting in 1993—but, nevertheless, as chairman of that area later concurring—who got 16 C-class shares at $1 each which, within three years, have a minimum value, because they cannot be established at the maximum, of $2.3 million. He has to explain that to the battlers. How many battlers can go out and get given sixteen $1 shares that have a value three years later of $2.3 million? The income stream from those shares to the family investment company to the family trust in 1995 was $99,000. In 1996 the two payments into the family trust totalled $290,000. Not bad going for a battler. But the really strange thing is that Senator Parer cannot seem to remember any of this. He cannot remember the odd $99,000, the $149,000 and the $140,000 cheques coming in.

talk.start.para: —Small change.

—You are right, Senator Evans. Is it small change? Those things should be answered. The biggest joke of all is that Senator Hill comes in here and says that the Prime Minister has cleared him, that it is okay by him. That has sent the boat out very quickly. Is the Prime Minister the one to really judge in this particular case? At least the Prime Minister says that he relies on the judgment of his senior public servant Mr Max Moore-Wilton, the most political appointee in the history since federation.

speech.para: It is so coincidental that he brings down his report on 9 May and then on 10 May at 9 o'clock in the morning the Prime Minister rings Dr Shergold and says, `I want you now to do a review of Mr Max Moore-Wilton's entitlements because the horrible senators have been raising it in the Senate committee the week before.' Then the same Dr Shergold gets promoted in December last year to departmental secretary.

If you want to bring in someone to judge this, bring in a neutral judge. Putting Max Moore-Wilton in charge of this particular investigation is like putting Dracula in charge of the blood bank. But if there is anyone I feel sorry for—and he does not want me to mention it—it is Senator Brian Gibson. Senator Brian Gibson left executive office for the most minuscule thing—nothing like this. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I call Senator Coonan.
—See if you can go for longer than one minute, which is all David MacGibbon could do.

—Yes, Senator Faulkner, I will certainly be going longer than a minute because isn't it about time that we got a bit of reality into this? This is approaching the farcical. Finally we get as an interjection from Senator Robert Ray that what seems to be worrying the opposition comes down to just a perception that there might be some infringement. For goodness sake!

speech.para: Isn't it about time that we, as the elected representatives of this country, actually addressed the real issues affecting the people of Australia rather than going on with this eternal trawling about things that real people out there do not seem to be really too worried about? Real people out there must be rubbing their eyes in disbelief at what has taken the time of this chamber for the last couple of days. The real issues and the real problems do not seem to be of the remotest concern to Senator Ray, Senator Faulkner and those in the opposition.

I wonder how many people are actually lying awake at night wondering about Senator Parer's family trust. There is not one shred of evidence to suggest that Senator Parer has ever misused his office for any improper purpose or even an allegation that he has been guilty of some actual conflict of interest. Not only is this a grubby exercise; it shows the utter lack of appreciation by those on the other side of how a trust actually works. We do not really know whether whoever is feeding all this stuff to the opposition has ever really looked at the memorandum and articles of association of this company. Senator Ray seems to be aware that we are looking at C class shares, which invariably have restrictions, and, of course, Senator Parer has said until he is practically blue in the face that the trust has 16 non-voting shares. We almost need to put the words to a song here—`16 non-voting shares'—but the message does not seem to be getting through.

It is very difficult to value shares, and certainly we question the sorts of values of non-voting shares that have been tossed around here at random as Senator Ray sought to do when he took note. These are not publicly listed shares. They are certainly not easily divested. They are very difficult to market. I think Senator Cook said all you have to do is consent to sell the shares in Queensland Coal Mine Management Pty Ltd. That's a laugh! If it were that easy to get rid of non-voting shares, I am sure a lot of people would do so with alacrity.

The truth of the matter is that you do not have much control over non-voting shares, and certainly very few people want to buy them if they cannot exercise any vote in relation to their interest. So the matter of whether or not there is a market for non-voting shares is critical in this case, and it is certainly one that ought to excuse Senator Parer from having to adopt the sort of wild values that have been tossed around in this chamber.

Quite apart from the fact that there has been no conflict of interest at all, there is further evidence—and I cannot believe that those on the other side of the chamber would not accept Senator Parer on this—that he has obtained no personal benefit from his ministerial responsibilities. That is really the critical issue. There is absolutely nothing to suggest that he has ever had any personal benefit from his office. Senator Parer has not breached the ministerial guidelines and the worst that can be said is that there is some technical breach of the Senate explanatory note. Are you really going to seek to hang Senator Parer for this? As I said when I started my speech, let us get a bit of reality into this debate. It is time that this is played out. I say to honourable senators on the other side, give it a rest.

talk.start.para: —That was an amazing speech; I don't know that it would hold up anywhere but in this chamber. This question is about probity in public office and, most of all, it is about the integrity of the Prime Minister. It is about that because the Prime Minister himself declared to the Australian electorate before the election that he would bring new standards, and after the election he did. Although they embodied most of the ministerial handbook, he declared what those standards are and they are on the public record. The particular standard under debate here is:

speech.para: Ministers are required to divest themselves of all shares and similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of their portfolio responsibilities.
The transfer of interests to a family member or to a nominee or trust is not an acceptable form of divestment.

That is the Prime Minister's own standard. We have just heard that that is fine as long as you can't say that the person has benefited from them in his own right. That is a preposterous notion. It says, in the Prime Minister's own standards, that there cannot be any `apparent conflict' between the exercise of public duty and that of the private potential gain of the individual minister.

It is not just a matter here of whether there was an actual conflict; it is also a matter of whether there is a potential conflict and it is also a matter of whether there is an appearance of conflict. This is the well trodden area of law that justice has to be done and justice has to be seen to be done. Both precepts have to be met. Let us compare this case with what happened to Senator Short. On 14 October 1996 the Prime Minister said, in the case of Senator Short after he had resigned, that there was `an apparent conflict of interest'. Those are the words of the Prime Minister in the case of Senator Short.

Where are those words now? Does the Prime Minister uphold his own standards? He has been silent on this. He will not answer that question. He needs to set his consistency on the line. He either upholds the standards he has imposed or he does not. And if he does not he is a hypocrite and he never intended those standards to be upheld anyway. It was simply a way of gulling the Australian electorate.

Short said at the time that he had made a `careless and distressing oversight'. He confessed to an apparent conflict of interest. We have here a similar confession to an apparent conflict of interest by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer), who has said, in a quaint way of putting it, `I made a technical mistake.' There is no provision for technical; you either made one or you didn't and a confession of a mistake is a confession of a mistake. He also went on to say that he did not read the letter that alerted him to what his public duty was. Since when was that a defence? Try standing up in a court and saying that you did not know what the law was and therefore you are innocent. That is exactly what is being said here. Why should that standard apply to ordinary Australians and not to a minister of the Crown? Why can a minister of the Crown say, `I didn't know; therefore I am innocent,' but an ordinary Australian say, `I didn't know what the law was,' and be convicted? That is a direct comparison of their hypocrisy on this matter.

There is a series of comparisons I would like to make—and I know that I will not have time to complete the list—between Senator Short's conduct and the conduct we are now witnessing from Senator Parer. Senator Short confessed to owning 6,679 ANZ shares, through the Short family trust, worth approximately $64,000 at the time of his resignation. Senator Parer owns just over one per cent of the issued capital in QCMM Pty Ltd, worth an estimated $2.3 million. Is it because of the higher value of the shares that a different level of conduct is acceptable? Is it because Senator Short was a supporter of the Prime Minister but not a personal mate, as is Senator Parer? Is that why a different standard of conduct is acceptable? Is that what it means?

Senator Short went on to say that he had held the shares in the trust, the ANZ Bank, for a considerable amount of time and that this holding had been recorded in the Register of Senators' Interests since its inception. Parer claims, as some sort of defence, that the trust has been in existence for 28 years and that he has a one-ninth interest in it. This must mean that he is one of nine family beneficiaries. At least Short declared it.

talk.start.para: —Senator Cook, could you please use their correct titles?
—At least Senator Short declared it; Senator Parer did not. (Time expired)

—I too would like to enter this debate and make a number of points. It is quite obvious from the tactics we have seen here involving our colleague Senator Parer and what occurred last week that the Labor Party came back after the break with one intent, and that was to sling mud, slur and try to pick individuals out and not deal with the issues that are required to be dealt with today—particularly when we have the Native Title Amendment Bill coming back into this place. This is just a sloppy, dirty diversion away from the real issues facing Australia.

speech.para: We hear from those on the other side about Senator Parer using the words `technical breach', which he did. But I have never heard such a mishmash of argument as that put before us in that last contribution from Senator Cook. You could not even call it a technical argument. In fact, one could quite fairly and freely say that Senator Cook mislead this place when he said that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) remained silent on this. Aren't you aware that the Prime Minister went into the other place last night and made a statement? For your benefit I will quote it. I will read out a couple of these points:
I inform the House that I am satisfied on the basis of the advice I have received since question time that Senator Parer has not breached the ministerial guidelines.

That is from the Prime Minister himself. If the Prime Minister stands up in the other place and says that, then I am satisfied. He also made a number of other points, as Senator Parer has done: there was no personal benefit out of the arrangements that were put in place; there is no conflict of interest in carrying out his job. These are very important aspects of what we have here before us at this particular time.

I had the benefit not so long ago of being in Kalgoorlie with Senator Parer. What did he do? He got on and dealt with the issues before us. In Kalgoorlie he discussed the problems that the goldfields and the mineral fields of Western Australia have with native title, which I have already mentioned. He talked about the issues of transport, the problems there and the need for infrastructure development to assist in the great industries we have in my state in those particular areas. There was no conflict of interest whatsoever or any pretence of conflict of interest in what Senator Parer was doing in carrying out his particular job and in performing his responsibilities as a minister. And to try to run a comparison between other people and Senator Parer and his particular position is absolutely a nonsense argument and position to be in. Senator Cook has left the chamber. He may have aspired at one time to be a lawyer but after that contribution he has a long way to go. He is certainly no Rumpole as far as I am concerned.

Returning to the issues that are very important: there is no conflict of interest, no profit and no voting rights. What more do you want from a particular individual? What amazes me most is, and it also applies to the Democrats and that silly question that was asked by their leader, Senator Meg Lees today: why do they so desperately hate anybody who is successful? I thought we should have this place full of successful people—people who know how to run a business, how to do things, how to be successful. I doubt whether you can find one senator on the other side who has ever made a buck of their own, who has ever taken their shirt off their back and done a decent day's hard work. And here you are attacking the man who has done it himself. He is a self-made person who has contributed an enormous amount to this economy of ours. You should be congratulating him for his performance.

talk.start.para: —Take your shirts off!

—Yes, take your shirts off, absolutely. You have never risked a dollar of your own or put a bit of risk capital out in the investment field. This is really just a slur campaign to try to put individuals down and a refusal to address the issues.
—Like Senator Bolkus.
—We saw today another rise in employment, albeit a small one, but it is coming up. You mention Senator Bolkus. What did he do? He is trying to keep Skase out of the country—
—You slurred him.
—I did not slur Senator Bolkus. He brought it on his own head. He read out confidential documents and got caught; that is what happened to Senator Bolkus. He absolutely trapped himself in.

speech.para: I come back to this matter. Why do you hate somebody who makes a profit and makes a success? At the end of the day there is no conflict of interest. The Prime Minister has looked at the issue very carefully and he is satisfied, and if the Prime Minister of this country is satisfied with that particular explanation, so am I, and so should everyone else in this chamber be.

talk.start.para: —There are two fundamental questions involved here. There is the question of whether or not Senator Parer has been open and direct in his declarations to this parliament under the pecuniary interest requirements of the Senate, and there is the issue as to whether or not the Prime Minister has failed in his duty to uphold the ministerial guidelines that he himself has flourished as a great hallmark of his government and the allegedly higher standards that he is representing in this country at the moment.

speech.para: In the first instance, it is undoubtedly the case, as Senator Parer himself acknowledges, that there has been at the very minimum, on his own admission, a technical breach. There is a more fundamental question, however, as to whether or not that technical breach goes to the issue of whether there has been a more fundamental conflict of interest between his activities as the minister for coal and his ownership of shares in coalmining in this country.

For the Prime Minister, however, there is a more substantial question still—not that the issues regarding Senator Parer in themselves are trifling affairs. What the Prime Minister said in regard to Jim Short when he laid down the benchmark here on 10 October 1996 was that he felt that, although Senator Short, as he then was, did in fact breach the guidelines, it was only a minor breach. That was his first position. He said that he thought that, while he believed that Senator Short did not comply and had acknowledged that to the Senate, he had discussed the matter with Senator Short. He had considered sacking him but he felt that, because there was no personal benefit directly to the Assistant Treasurer, as he was at the time, that he had made no consideration directly to benefit himself, as he saw it, it involved no impropriety. So Senator Short, as he was then, ought not be forced from the ministry. He said:

I think anybody who knows Senator Short will be aware that he has not been guilty of any deliberate dishonesty. In all the circumstances, I do not believe that he has profited from any deliberate decisions. I do not think the ownership of those ANZ Bank shares influenced decisions that he took. In those circumstances, I have taken the decision that I have and I remain confident of the minister's capacity.

Of course, the problem for Senator Short and for the Prime Minister was that by the weekend, by 11 October 1996, Minister Short was writing a letter to the Prime Minister resigning his portfolio. He said that he had become aware, as a result of staff going through his papers, that he had in fact undertaken a number of decisions involving ANZ interests. What he said in a letter to the Prime Minister was that he had found several dozen approvals relating to the administration of banking laws. In his letter to Mr Howard, according to the Sydney Morning Herald of 14 October, Senator Short said that the ANZ request was a routine one and his approval had been based on the recommendation of both the Reserve Bank and the Treasurer. There were no grounds on which the request might have been decided differently. He said:

My approval was influenced in no way whatsoever by the fact of my shareholding in the ANZ Bank. When I spoke with you on Wednesday evening I had not recalled having given the particular approval, and similarly during the Senate sittings on the Thursday. Now my attention has been drawn to that approval, I feel that the circumstances of the matter have changed, and in light of this I have given the deepest consideration to the circumstances and I have decided to tender to you my resignation as Assistant Treasurer.
What is a difference between Senator Short, as he then was, and Senator Parer now?

talk.start.para: —Order! The time for debate has expired.
—by leave—On behalf of Senator Watson, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, he will move:

speech.para: That the Select Committee on Superannuation be authorised to hold a public meeting during the sitting of the Senate on 23 March and 24 March 1998, from 7 p.m., to take evidence for the committee's inquiry into the provisions of the Commonwealth Superannuation Board Bill 1997 the Superannuation Legislation (Commonwealth Employment) Repeal and Amendment Bill 1997 and the Superannuation Legislation (Commonwealth Employment—Saving and Transitional Provisions) Bill 1997.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the President, I present a document entitled Work of committees for the period 1 January to 31 December 1997.

interjection.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —The President has received letters from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and an independent senator seeking variations to the membership of certain committees.

interjection.para: That senators be discharged from and appointed to committees as follows:
Employment, Education and Training References Committee—
Participating member: Senator Carr for the committee's inquiry into employment levels and regional unemployment
Substitute member: Senator Mackay to replace Senator Carr for the committee's inquiry into employment levels and regional unemployment
Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee—
Substitute member: Senator Lundy to replace Senator Forshaw for the consideration of the provisions of the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Amendment Bill 1997.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: The Senate notes, with concern, that:
(a) despite coming to office pledging to reduce youth and long-term unemployment by boosting economic growth, the policies of the Howard Government have in fact delivered:
(i) a 15 per cent increase in long-term unemployment since March 1996,
(ii) a fall in employment growth from 2.9 per cent per year during the last term of the Labor Government, to 1.4 per cent per year under the Coalition,
(iii) an increase in the youth unemployment rate from 27.4 per cent to 28.4 per cent since March 1996, and
(iv) a fall in economic growth from 4.7 per cent to 3.6 per cent since March 1996;

(b) the Government's response to this disastrous employment picture has been to contract out the responsibility for its failures by abolishing the Commonwealth Employment Service and introducing a `market-based' approach to employment services, without parliamentary scrutiny and excluding many hundreds of community-based employment service providers with excellent track records and priceless intellectual property;

(c) the Government has introduced this fundamentally flawed employment policy with a tender process which has been secretive, has demonstrated no link between resource allocation and need, and fails to deal with ongoing issues such as performance monitoring and purchaser/provider dispute resolution; and

(d) the Government's policy, despite being promoted as more flexible and effective, is no more than a cynical measure designed to artificially deliver a lower long-term unemployment rate by actively excluding from the employment services market 400 000 unemployed people who are not on benefits, people over 50 and people who have been in case management for more than 39 weeks.

I thought I would start off by anticipating the speakers from the government who will, no doubt, talk about the unemployment figures that were released today. I would like to point out, before the chortling from the government, that what we have is a flatline employment situation. Employment is stuck at 8.1 per cent. The other key fact is that there has been no improvement whatsoever in youth unemployment since this government was elected.

I would like to go through the economic situation because I am sick to death of the nonsense coming from Peter Costello with regard to the economic situation in Australia and the selective quoting of statistics that he is so good at. Let us have a look at it.

One figure they do not talk a lot about on the other side of the chamber is growth. The reality is that last week's national account figures showed economic growth for the year to December as 3.6 per cent. You cannot get genuine employment growth in an economy unless you get over the hurdle of four per cent to 4.5 per cent growth. Who said that? Who said you have to get at least four per cent growth before you can make a real dint in unemployment? I bet you he has rued the day he made the statement. It was the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, who said that. Yet in the whole two years that this government has been in they have not cracked the four per cent. What was the growth rate when Labor went out of office? It was 4.6 per cent. So in two years of coalition government growth has dropped. That is the first point. It was probably a non-core promise but it was a commitment by this government that it would get growth above four per cent. But what has happened is that, under the policies of this government, growth has reduced by one per cent. That is an indictment in itself. But there is more.

Let us have a look at the situation with regard to the average rate of economic growth achieved under the Howard government. Average economic growth is three per cent. In Labor's last term of office the average rate of growth was 4.5 per cent. That is a 1½ per cent difference. In Labor's full 13 years in office the average annual rate of economic growth was 3.7 per cent—more, right through the recession in the early 1990s, than this government has managed to achieve in two years when the commitment was four per cent. In the calendar year 1997, the first full year of the Howard government, the economy grew by just 2.8 per cent, despite an OECD prediction of 2.9 per cent.

Let us go through this litany of mismanagement. The transport industry also recorded negative growth in the December quarter of minus one per cent. Corporate profit, something they are very fond of trumpeting here, actually fell by 0.4 per cent in the quarter. Despite the fact that inflation continues to remain low, the major deflators—private consumption and GDP—all show a rise in inflation. Let us have a look at savings. The household saving ratio fell from 3.9 per cent to 3.1 per cent. The ratio was 3.6 per cent when Labor left office. The manufacturing sector, a very important sector and a major job creator, recorded negative growth of minus 0.6 per cent in the December quarter. That is outrageous in such a labour intensive sector.

Employment growth since March 1996 has averaged just 1.4 per cent compared to almost three per cent under Labor. Long-term unemployment, the most serious and difficult form of unemployment to deal with, has risen 15 per cent since the Prime Minister took the axe to Working Nation. This is outrageous. As I said before, in the entire term of this government there has been no improvement in youth unemployment, despite the commitment they gave that youth unemployment was a high priority. Secondly, we have a situation where, as I said before, 8.1 per cent is flatline.

The economy, the government says, is going really well. It says the preconditions are there and all we have to do is wait. To quote the previous minister for employment, Senator Vanstone, it is a bit like a farmer waiting for the drought to break. The drought still has not broken and the reason the drought still has not broken is that nothing has happened in this economy under this government for two years.

talk.start.para: —Hasn't it?
—That is right. Nothing has happened. A growth rate of 3.6 per cent is not a good result. It is a shocking result, Senator Calvert. It was 4.6 per cent when we left office.

speech.para: Let us have a look at the figures today. The number of full-time jobs fell in Australia in February by 7,000. Do you know why? Because what this government is doing is creating a casualised and part-time work force, and the strategy is absolutely deliberate.

One of the most important things that came out yesterday was the consumer confidence figures. I wonder if anybody on the other side had a look at those. The consumer confidence figures fell in March by 10 per cent, which is the second largest monthly fall in this decade. That is extremely serious.

talk.start.para: —Ooh!

—Well you may go `Ooh!' but that is extremely serious. Consumer confidence falling by 10 per cent with the economy in such a difficult situation is very serious. With the Asian crisis yet to hit it is very serious. If the people on the other side think it is funny then you do not deserve to get re-elected and you will not.

speech.para: What has the government done in the face of this situation? They have introduced the deregulation of the employment services market to supposedly help unemployed people. What a disaster that has been. I said it the other day and I will repeat it—

talk.start.para: —It hasn't even started yet. How can it be a disaster?

—That's right; it has not even started yet and look at all the disasters that are emerging already. It is one of the most mismanaged, maladministered messes that I have ever seen. I think it is the most mismanaged, maladministered mess that this government has created. That is the reality.

speech.para: How did all of this commence? The previous minister for employment, Senator Vanstone, introduced a bill. The opposition was successful in getting amendments to that bill, which included a reference to universality and which included reference to a public service. No way. The government did not like that. The bill was pulled; they ran away. They could not take the heat. They could not take the public scrutiny so they pulled the bill. They proceeded anyway and what an absolute disaster that has been.
If you do not believe me—as I am sure those on the other side do not—listen to what the Australian of 28 February 1998 had to say about this new market approach to employment services. It says:
Providing a bounty of up to $10,000 for a successful job placement for someone who is defined as long-term unemployed seems, however, a system ripe for exploitation.
They got it in one. They were absolutely correct—`ripe for exploitation'. Gary Hardgrave, the Liberal member from Queensland, said:
I am angry about the awarding of contracts because many community providers with strong records of helping the unemployed missed out on contracts.
So, if you do not believe the opposition and the Australian editorial, what about one of your own people who made that statement? He should be angry because that is exactly what happened.

Let us revisit—and see if we can actually get it through to the government—what is happening with the 400,000 people who will not be eligible for employment services. Let us just go through it one more time because we still have not had assurances from the government in relation to it. The reality is: if you are unemployed and not on benefit, you are not entitled to access to employment services for free.

talk.start.para: —And you never were under Labor.

—With the CES you were. We have heard nothing but weasel words from Dr Kemp with regard to this. He is saying, `Nobody will be turned away in terms of access.' I think Senator Ellison may have said the same thing. What does that mean—that you are not going to be thrown out of an office when you walk in? I want this government to give an absolute guarantee that every single person who is unemployed will have free access to employment services. That is what we want. We want that guarantee.

speech.para: Let us revisit the long-term unemployment figures. We have a situation where long-term unemployment has increased by 15 per cent under this government. What is the government doing for long-term unemployed people? If you are long-term unemployed and not on benefit, you do not get—and I said it the other day—a cracker. You do not get any assistance whatsoever. Let us just clarify this because you have to listen very carefully to what Dr Kemp and Minister Ellison have said in relation to this. If you are not on benefit, you will not get assistance. If you have been unemployed for 12 months, you will not get assistance. Who said this? Not the opposition—Employment National. Employment National said, `Sorry, we're interested in profit. We're running things on a market basis. If somebody, not on benefit, has been registered as long-term unemployed for 12 months, we will not help them. We are in the business of making a profit.' That is fine; I cannot blame them for that because this government set up that precondition. Again, Minister, I would be very interested if this government would give a commitment that every single person who is long-term unemployed and not necessarily on benefit will be given access to employment services to the same extent as those people who are long-term unemployed and on benefit. That is what we want.

Access to employment services for the retrenched worker who is living off his or her redundancy payments is denied. We still have not had an assurance to free services for defence force personnel spouses because they are not on benefit. Minister, I would be very pleased if you would give a rock-solid commitment—not a core or non-core commitment—that you will guarantee that these people will be given access to employment services. Women wishing to re-enter the work force with partners who work—the ones who can actually afford child care these days, given the cuts to child care—are denied access to employment services. They cannot get it. This really is an outrage. People know it is an outrage, and I would suggest that you are not going to get away with it. Tom Connors from the West Australian said on 11 March:
Jobless Australians deserve a free employment service. Only the heartless would say otherwise.
Only the heartless would say that. This government is heartless and mean spirited.

You could go on and on about this disaster. Let us have a look at the resource allocation. How were FLEX 3 resources allocated, Minister? Were they allocated on the basis of long-term unemployment? They were not. FLEX 3 resources were not allocated on the basis of long-term unemployment. There is no nexus between FLEX 3 allocation and long-term unemployment rates. Do you know what you have done? I know what you have done. You have done actually allocated resources on the basis of job opportunities, not where long-term unemployed people actually are. Let me explain what you have done because I know what you have done. It is very simple. It is allocated on the basis of job opportunities. That means that you—the government—have given more resources disproportionately to those areas where people have more chance of getting a job. That is why the major factor in relation to FLEX 3 allocation is job opportunities.

What does that do? It means that long-term unemployed people who are lucky enough to live in areas where there are jobs will get them—let us hope that they do—and those long-term unemployed people who live in areas where there is not enough FLEX 3 allocated will not. What will they get? They will get work for the dole. What will we have? We will have jobless ghettos. If this government is serious about saying to the Australian people that the allocation of FLEX 3 for long-term unemployed people—that is, intensive assistance—was done on a fair dinkum basis, show us the modelling. Show us how you did it. Show us how you actually got the figures and show us how it was allocated. I, for one, would be extremely interested to see it.

How did the minister, Dr Kemp, deliver the so-called good news about this new service? I think I have already indicated that there were some real doubts about the allocation of FLEX 3 in relation to the tender documents. Did the minister say that there are X number of FLEX 3 places—that is, intensive assistance—for here and there are X number of places for there? No, he gave ticks. If you have a look at his papers, you will see that there are ticks—FLEX 3, tick; FLEX 1, tick. He did not indicate how many places. It was quite deliberate. In the press conference he obfuscated when asked that question by journalists. He would not give that response. Why? The reality is that the resources have diminished. There is a cut. We will find out about this.

When Dr Kemp made the announcement, he set himself some benchmarks, which is very interesting. It is good that we have benchmarks, but it is a pity that we do not have a jobs target. One benchmark is that during the first 19 months 840,000 will be matched vacancies. What does that mean? Does it mean that 840,000 people will get jobs or does it mean matched? Perhaps you can clarify that, Minister Ellison. Does it mean they will get the jobs? I do not think so. Here again are weasel words.

The second lot says that 540,000 will be given intensive assistance—that is, FLEX 3. Do you know what that means? It means they will go along to a provider and get registered. It is $1,500 in the provider's pocket. That is what Dr Kemp means when he says that 540,000 will be given intensive assistance. That is why they are called FLEX 3 commencements in the tender documents. I suggest you read it, Minister. These so-called benchmarks and targets are arrant nonsense.

What happens to the long-term unemployed job seekers who go along to the provider and get put on the books and remain on there for 52 weeks? If they are really hard cases, after 52 weeks they are put off the provider's books. Do you know what they have to do then? They have to wait to requalify for intensive assistance and all they are entitled to is FLEX 1.

I would like to spend the remaining time looking at what this flawed and biased tendering process delivered. Let us look at what happened to those hardworking, committed people in the community sector and the private sector who missed out. Mary-Louise Petro of Sisters of Mercy, St Mary's—this issue has had a lot of coverage—was quoted in the Financial Review as saying:
We are having to close Mamre Employment Services in St Mary's. We have made 10 highly efficient staff redundant.

Let us look at some case studies. Key Training, established in 1989, has been providing case management services in Tasmania since 1995 and has a placement rate of 43 per cent, which is 6.3 per cent higher than the CES itself and other similar providers in the region. Key Training has received numerous industry awards—too many to mention here—and under the recent round of tenders got nothing. As a result of this, 12 staff are being retrenched at Key Training.

Victoria's Strategic Training and Employment Placement Services, STEPS, which was established in 1996, has been providing case management services at Broadmeadows since that time. Both the principals of this organisation have been working with the long-term unemployed for over 30 years and were previously CES area managers. It has a placement rate of 34 per cent, which is four per cent higher than EEA and other similar providers. It did not get anything either and is expecting to retrench four experienced staff as a result.

I conclude by saying that this is a disaster. This is why day after day the government is getting community provider after community provider saying the process was a shonk, the results are a shonk and they will not deliver any genuine services to unemployed people, particularly to the area most in need—that is, the long-term unemployed.

talk.start.para: —Considering the experience of 13 years of Labor government, I find it very difficult to believe that we are here debating this motion today. Senator Mackay, since you feel so strongly about the unemployed, you might stay in the chamber for the debate. Today of all days we have had the best job news for over seven years. The ABS announced today that 8,529,000 people are in work in Australia—the highest number ever in Australia's history. There was an increase of 14,800 in February alone and and increase of 140,600 jobs in the six months to February. Listen to this, Senator Mackay: the seasonal unemployment rate is at 8.1 per cent, the lowest since December 1990—more than seven years. Today there are 8,529,000 people in employment in Australia—the highest number in Australia's history.

speech.para: But this government is not going to rest on its laurels. The coalition is committed to working towards the goal of giving a job to every Australian who wants a job. It is a goal we are proud of. It is a legitimate goal that only a government that genuinely cares for the people of Australia could have. It is a goal which in 13 years the ALP never even tried to reach. Unemployment rates went up under the ALP, and let us never ever forget it. When this government came into office we pledged to reduce youth and long-term unemployment by boosting economic growth. I must say that our record is far better than that of those who sit on the other side of the chamber and seek to trivialise the debate today.

In the `recession we had to have' the ALP destroyed 338,900 jobs; let us think about that another way: 338,900 people's lives. I hope you are proud of that. When Mr Beazley was minister for employment, long-term unemployment increased by 95,000 people. In the six years from July 1990 to March 1996, when the ALP was in government, only 16,000 full-time jobs were created—in six years. It is laughable that you come into this chamber today and wish to debate the coali tion government's record on employment creation.

We have created 14,800 places of employment in February alone. You created 16,000 in six years. What a pathetic effort. We all remember when unemployment reached 11.2 per cent in December 1992—the highest level of unemployment in the postwar era. That was under your government: congratulations to you. We all remember when from March 1991 to November 1994, nearly three years, unemployment did not fall below nine per cent; and when in December 1992 youth unemployment reached 31.4 per cent. Incidentally, in today's figures it is down to 26.4 per cent. Under you, it was 31.4 per cent; it is now down to 26.4 per cent.

talk.start.para: —That is nothing to be proud of.

—We are not resting on our laurels; as I have said, we will continue to do anything within our power to give a job to every person in this country who wants one. None of us will ever forget the 1.3 million Australians who, under Labor, could not find the level of employment they wanted. Who can forget those billboards all around Australia: one million unemployed?

speech.para: I am not necessarily blaming Senator Mackay for the policies of the Captain Wacky government. Given that the senator was never part of that government, I can only assume that she is as embarrassed by its record as we on this side of the chamber are disgusted, because when Senator Mackay raises the issue of unemployment in this chamber she never mentions Labor's record. She is ashamed of it.

The Hawke-Keating governments did spend money though. As I have said before and will doubtless say again: Labor governments are very, very good at spending money. Working Nation, the $12 billion disaster, springs immediately to mind—or Non-Working Nation, as it was called by many. Many of those young people who were churned through training program after training program after training program called it Training Nation.

The Labor government's message to young people was that being on the dole was an acceptable alternative to education and training, an acceptable alternative to looking for work. Let the Australian people never forget that, under Working Nation, when you were in a training program, you were considered to be working. What a joke. What a manipulation of the unemployment figures. It is something of which I think you should be ashamed.

In the Bulletin last year, the attitude instilled by the Labor Party was showcased in an unemployment snapshot of young people living at Broken Head. Johnny Abegg, 17, left school early and is on the dole because `it helps out the oldies'. Matt Chelman, 21, who has not worked since leaving school:
We're all on the dole. You get addicted to it after a while . . . Look, I'm happy on the dole. It suits me and it keeps you out of trouble.
These are our young people, the future of our country—and I hold the ALP directly responsible for this attitude.

But this is not surprising, when you consider the labour market programs that Labor devised. In 1995-96 the ALP spent $2.7 billion on labour market programs, and unemployment rose. But Labor's labour market programs did not work. Take New Work Opportunities, for example, a labour market program which had an outcome of 21 per cent. Not too bad, you might think. But, when compared with a comparison control group of 17 per cent, the outcome was four per cent—four per cent net outcome and $143,000 a place. But, in addition, most of those people had already taken part in a previous training program; that is, more money on labour market programs which did not fix the problem—the training merry-go-round. Is it any wonder that Johnny Abegg and Matt Chelman think it is easier to stay on the dole?

The Democrats phrased it well—and I regret the fact that Senator Stott Despoja has left the chamber—when they said in their unemployment issues paper, `The Working Nation program is not about creating new jobs but reshuffling the unemployed.' This same paper of the Democrats also concludes, `a goal of every Australian having work is an impossibility'—an impossibility. Well, you have sold out the Australian public too soon.

In 1994 the OECD made a statement about training programs like Working Nation. After a comprehensive study of developed countries' traditional responses to unemployment and their training programs, such as Working Nation, the OECD concluded that there was `meagre support for the hypothesis that such programs are effective'—meagre support.

Money is not the answer. We do have an unemployment problem in this country, and the unemployed people out there deserve some innovative creative responses. We cannot continue with the responses of the last two decades which have not worked in Australia and, according to the OECD, have not worked in any other country, just because you are not imaginative enough or courageous enough to tackle new things. This government is.

talk.start.para: —You haven't done anything.
—Let me tell you, Senator Hogg, what our results are—
—Order! Address the Chair please, Senator Synon.

—I am sorry, Madam Deputy President—116,100 new full-time jobs: the strongest job growth in 2½ years. In the past five months under our government, there has been the creation of 141,800 new jobs. As I said before, that translates into a seven-year low of unemployment rate of 8.1 per cent.

speech.para: Yes, we have replaced the old CES—and, yes, it needed to be replaced. It had a success rate of less than 20 per cent and was not providing adequate service to Australians. So it had to go. And, yes, we have introduced the new Job Network, a system which will be more flexible, more responsive and infinitely more successful. On 1 May Job Network will replace the CES. Job Network is our national network involving more than 300 private community and government organisations, which will specialise in finding jobs for unemployed people. We are going to focus on results, getting unemployed people into jobs, giving people help that actually makes a difference.

And, yes, we are using a market based approach. We are actually going to pay Job Network members for placing unemployed people in jobs. We are going to provide incentives for job placement organisations to find unemployed people jobs. The more disadvantaged the status of the person, the greater the incentive. This government is not about managing or reshuffling the unemployed. It is about finding them jobs.

Job Network is a great opportunity for unemployed people. It is going to offer access to thousands more vacancies on a touch screen vacancy database and access to 1,404 sites around Australia, instead of the fewer than 300 sites the CES offered—over 700 more outlets for unemployed people to go to. That is four times the number of points of access to service for unemployed people. We are going to provide them with improved access to free computers, telephones and facsimiles to help them prepare resumes, apply for jobs and find work; flexible assistance—assistance actually tailored to the needs of the individual job seeker; and easier access, most importantly, to apprenticeships and traineeships. Apprenticeships, under the previous government, fell to their lowest level in more than 30 years.

By offering greater choice to employees and employers we are letting them decide what they want and what services they want to use. It does work. The Westgate Community Initiatives Group in Footscray, Melbourne, a highly successful and professional community based nonprofit organisation, offers personalised service to its clients, who find it has a more comfortable and individualised environment. One of their unemployed people, Despina Sarandogiou, said—I want senators to listen to this:
Here I feel like a person whereas at the CES I felt like a number.
Is that how those opposite would have our young people think of themselves—as a number in a bureaucratic machine? Not this government. We are treating these people as people.

But Senator Mackay's motion also, surprisingly, criticises our tender process—something which I am finding hard to accept in light of its rigour. We put in place an outstanding process to select the best people in Australia to provide Job Network services. Every one of them went through a very rigorous process to test their suitability and financial viability. Every one of them had to devise a strategy to help unemployed people in their area, and every one of them had to undertake satisfactory access for unemployed people to their services. They all had to demonstrate their experience, and they all had to compete.

Senator Mackay and others were at estimates and heard this process discussed and have a copy of Mr Sedgewick's statements outlining the terms covering the tender process. They know that experienced departmental staff assessed approximately 5,000 bids for six service types within 29 labour market regions against stated selection criteria. The ALP know that the principles established in allocating levels of business to tenderers included competition, client choice, diversity, value for money and coverage for as many job seekers in the market as possible. They know that to meet these principles a wide range of providers were selected—over 300 of them.

They also know, and have been told repeatedly, that Blake Dawson Waldron, a highly respected law firm, was appointed to independently monitor procedural integrity throughout the tender, and they know that they gave this process an unqualified sign-off on 24 February. Their statement reads:

On the basis of our observation and inquiries of the Independent Observers we are satisfied that . . . the tender has been conducted in accordance with the probity requirements. We consider that the procedures outlined in the published tender documentation including the Probity Plan, have been followed . . . we have not identified any evidence of systematic bias, lack of objectivity by assessment teams, pattern of scoring or ranking which advantaged or disadvantaged any particular bidder.

The independent observers are happy. Of course, each tenderer has also been offered the opportunity to be debriefed on how they fared, so it can hardly be called a secretive process. And of course safeguards have been built into the Job Network system. Contracts with Job Network organisations preclude them from charging eligible job seekers for employment services. Job seekers will be afforded protection such as client privacy and the right for complaints to be referred to the Ombudsman. An industry code of conduct lays down standards that organisations must follow, and that code is backed up by a complaints process available to anyone unhappy with the service they receive.

For the first time in almost 20 years of employment service delivery we are offering unemployed people a choice. Just because that does not sit comfortably with the socialist notions expounded on the other side is no reason to criticise the program. Choice should be available to everyone, even the unemployed.

As for the comments regarding the long-term unemployed and their exclusion from the employment services market of various groups in the community, they are just another example of Labor's misrepresentation of the facts and blatant twisting of fundamental truths. The long-term unemployed will be specifically targeted and receive intensive personalised case management. If they are going to get a job, they are going to get it under a program like this—not Working Nation, not LEAP, not Jobskills.

Let me take on another point—that people who are not registered for benefits are not going to be eligible for services. Let me tell those opposite, based on my many years of experience in this area, that people who are not in receipt of unemployment benefits have never been eligible for intensive government assistance—training or otherwise. There were many times when I was managing an employment training program in the western suburbs of Melbourne that I rang the DEET officers and wanted to provide assistance to someone and was told the government—that is the ALP government—thought it was not an economically viable option. So let us put a nonsense to this argument that we keep hearing.

Again we have the ALP wasting its time and our valuable time criticising our record and our policy on unemployment. We are the ones out there creating the jobs, helping job seekers find jobs and providing a responsive, flexible system to assist them. Our government cares enough about the unemployed to try to help. We do not just throw money at them. We do not just reshuffle their numbers. Our government cares enough that we have done something about unemployment, and the record speaks for itself. Today 8,522,000 people in Australia are in work—the highest level in the history of this country; an increase of 14,800 jobs in February alone. Over six years the ALP created just 16,000 jobs. We have created 140,600 jobs in the six months to February. The trend unemployment rate in this country today is 8.1 per cent—the lowest level for seven years.

The ALP should be ashamed of themselves. They are obviously ashamed of their record, because they never discuss it; they never open themselves up to scrutiny. This government does not need to shuffle numbers. This government does not need to shuffle the unemployed. This government is about getting jobs. This government is getting jobs and will continue to do so.

talk.start.para: —I rise on behalf of the Australian Democrats this afternoon to support the general business motion before us. We on many occasions and again today express our concern about the seemingly, at times, intractable problem of unemployment in this country, in particular our youth unemployment levels, as Senator Mackay has noted in her motion before us. I acknowledge some of the points that Senator Synon has made to the chamber and today we welcome any increase in job participation; we welcome any increase in employment statistics in this country.

speech.para: I think we all are very nervous and at times rather cynical about figures put before us. I just hope that increased employment opportunities and positions continue. But I also get concerned about those figures which reflect those people who are dropping out of looking for full-time work. I also get very concerned when we fail to analyse that a number of new jobs created have been generally, and in particular since the beginning of this coalition government, in the part-time and casual area—that we are seeing a reduction in the number of full-time jobs being created. It is that increased casualisation of the work force which is of grave concern.

I do take issue, though, with a point of Senator Synon's. She referred to the creative, the new and the innovative ideas of this government when it came to addressing the issue of employment. I could happily sit here all day—not necessarily all day, but for some time—and listen to Senator Synon expand on those new ideas. I did not get any new ideas, however. I think one of the strongest criticisms that many people in the community and certainly the Australian Democrats would make of this government is its absolute failure to invest in new industries—sustainable high-tech industries of the future; the kinds of industries where long-term, meaningful and sustainable jobs will come from, not just for young Australians but for a range of people in the community.

We know, too, that the link between job placement and increased employment opportunities in the future is with education and training opportunities. One of the biggest bugbears that the Democrats have with this government is the government's failure to recognise that link, or at least underestimating that link and the important role that education and training at any level plays in this process. Jobs of the future will be in these highly skilled industries. That is why Australians, but in particular young Australians, need access to education and training opportunities. They do not need disincentives, be they psychological or financial, put in their way. In relation to education and training opportunities, they do not need barriers such as fees, high levels of unmet demand and, as we have seen today, changes to income support arrangements, in particular for students and young unemployed people, that make it at times almost impossible to enter into those institutions.

I will confine most of my remarks this afternoon to where Senator Synon left off, and that is in relation to the employment tendering processes under this government. I am glad that Senator Synon expressed her satisfaction with the probity and accountability of these particular processes, because the Democrats are not satisfied. In fact it is with deepening concern that the Democrats have watched, if you like, the unfurling and now unravelling of the government's privatisation of the employment services market. We believe that this service is fundamentally flawed, both in operation and in implementation—the losers being the unemployed and the established and committed service providers for whom this government continues to display an appalling lack of regard.

We believe it is the sad truth that the more one looks into the operation of this scheme the more flaws one finds. At every level there is evidence of poor policy and poor decision making, and every day more comes to light. Today I have to add to this ever-growing list. I wish to highlight in particular the government's contravention of its international treaty obligations and its apparent lack of probity. The International Labour Organisation convention was ratified by this country in 1949; yet it appears that the current government either has forgotten about these provisions or hopes that the rest of Australia has forgotten. An examination of these provisions show that the employment tendering scheme certainly contravenes the spirit and the letter of that convention. I draw the attention of the Senate to article 1 of the convention which provides:
Each Member of the International Labour Organisation for which this convention is in force shall maintain or ensure the provision of a free public employment service.

When we look at the proposed operation of what remains of this public service, Employment National, we can see that it has been established on a commercial basis. It is to compete with other service providers and, as such, will be bound to maximise profits at the expense of the service it offers.

I note the minister has been very keen to assert that facilities will be available for those who need them, yet the facts are that the intensive FLEX 3 assistance will only be available to the long-term unemployed and other facilities will only be available to those on unemployment benefits.
