That leaves an estimated 420,000 people, such as those in part-time and casual employment—a growing proportion of our work force as I have pointed out—and the spouses of employed persons re-entering the job market without free access and assistance, in clear contravention of this article.

The minister is wrong in his view—and it is a view to which only he and his government appear to adhere—that the provision of touch screen services at Employment National, and Senator Synon referred to this, and other service providers will equate with one-to-one assistance. Furthermore, it is important to remember that Employment National has been set up on a commercial basis and of course it is going to be expected to operate on this basis. What incentive will exist for it and other service providers to list vacancies on their databases for universal access when they will not receive any payment when they are filled? These organisations will only be paid for the positions which they fill themselves, and it is an accepted view within the industry that the degree to which the positions will be listed will be very limited indeed.

Furthermore, the minister has claimed repeatedly, in lieu of formal safeguards to protect difficult to place unemployed persons, he will rely on `verbal assurances' given by providers. We heard the following comment from the minister on yesterday's AM program:
Drake have said that if they come to us we'd consider taking them for that job along with everyone else who was the best person for the job.
This is clearly no assurance whatsoever.

As these organisations will be operating on a for-profit basis and will be paid only for the people they place, what incentive exists for them to provide services for the disadvantaged or the long-term unemployed whom they may not consider to be the best person for the job? They are the hard people to place. There is nothing to stop these organisations from culling the people who come to them and providing services only to those whom they believe will be attractive candidates for employers.
Again we see the government in breach of its obligations under this convention, because part 2 of article 1 provides:

The essential duty of the employment services shall be to ensure, in cooperation where necessary with other public and private bodies concerned, the best possible organisation of the employment market as an integral part of the national programme for the achievement and maintenance of full employment and the development and use of productive resources.

The minister is certainly adept at making grand assertions, but I would defy even him to continue to claim that the outcome of the tender processes actually fulfils this part of the article. The most cursory glance will reveal serious anomalies and, unless action is taken to rectify this, the ramifications for those requiring the services will be all too severe.

Examples abound of established, experienced organisations—particularly community organisations and those with community links—losing out to organisations with little or, in some cases, no capacity to deliver the services for which they have been contracted. Organisations such as the National Skillshare Association have been decimated—an absolute tragedy—under this tendering process. Their years of expertise in service provision has been deemed of less worth than individuals with new ideas and approaches. I take on board Senator Synon's concerns about some of the former Labor government's projects—

talk.start.para: —Too right!

—Do not get ahead of yourself, Senator Tierney—in particular the Working Nation programs. There were flaws. However, what this government did was not only cut $1.8 billion over about three years out of labour market cetera programs, but it did not even give any credence to the notion that well-targeted labour market programs do assist and that there were organisations that had very good track records in the provision of places and the placing of those people who were unemployed, be it for short or longer periods of time.

speech.para: The Democrats have always acknowledged that that process needed time to be not only properly established, but evaluated. Then the idea of evaluation is to keep the good bits and get rid of the bad bits; not to get rid of the whole process altogether. We are fans of targeted labour market programs and that is why we were absolutely stunned and outraged when this government made such sweeping cuts to labour market programs in the 1996 budget, together with just about anything that involved education or training.

The minister is wrong when he claims that the previous system failed the unemployed. Skillshare is a great example of a successful program and successful placements in a very difficult sector. It managed to place more than half the people registered with it. I believe in its last year of operation it placed around 60,000 people. Since 1989 the association has placed more than one million unemployed people. That is a staggering amount when we think of the number of people who have been unemployed in this country.

Yet this was not good enough for the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs or the minister, and 250 of their 300 providers did not win contracts under the new scheme. When we look at how the new scheme is set to operate, we see examples such as Lismore which has one of the highest rates of youth unemployment in the country, as Senator Tierney would know. Yet, instead of ensuring that services are maintained in that area, they have been cut. Innovative, successful programs—some provided by ATSIC and designed to assist the indigenous population in the area—have also been cut.

Prior to the adoption of the new scheme, there were 56 clients per case manager in the area. Now there is only one case management provider, Employment National, and each case manager will have around 200 clients. This is unworkable, unfair and, even more sadly, it is a situation replicated throughout the country.
Article 2 of the convention provides:
The employment service shall consist of a national system of employment offices under the direction of a national authority.

The Australian Democrats would like to know why organisations with proven expertise lost out to those with little or no experience and why Employment National in particular was awarded a disproportionate amount—42 per cent—of the most lucrative work available, often at the expense of the smaller providers.

The outcome of the tendering processes has seen the creation of an anti-competitive market in which Employment National, with its huge market share—which stretches to a monopoly in some places, such as Lismore, which I mentioned—is poised to clean up. It has been handed the employment market on a plate. So we are seeking an assurance from the minister that the government has not handed Employment National the employment market on a plate so that it can be privatised at a future time. It is fattening up Employment National so it can be sold off, an act which would be in direct contravention of the provision that I just described in article 2 of the convention.
Moving through the convention, article 3 is yet another provision which the government has chosen to ignore. It states:

The system shall comprise of a network of local and, where appropriate, regional offices, sufficient in number to serve each geographical area of the country and conveniently located for employers and workers.

The $1.4 billion worth of cuts in funding to this sector has resulted in a decimation of the public provider. In May 1996 in my home state of South Australia, the CES operated a network of 31 offices and had 700 staff. Despite the fact that today's employment figures—Senator Synon was happy to talk about today's employment figures—reveal that the rate of participation in the labour market in South Australia is the lowest for years, with almost 5,000 people having given up looking for work, as of 1 May Employment National will have less than 100 staff in 17 locations. A number of these will be merely office shopfront locations and operations. Of particular concern is the effect that this will have on rural and regional areas.

The commercialisation of the market has seen a parallel urbanisation of service provision with providers choosing to establish themselves in the more lucrative urban locations. The result of this has been that places such as Coober Pedy, Ceduna, Naracoorte in the south-east, rural areas and some regional areas with high levels of unemployment, will no longer have employment service providers.

Given the contempt with which the government has approached this whole process and the contempt that it has displayed in its obligations towards the unemployed and the service providers—the list goes on—it is perhaps not surprising that an analysis of the tendering process has thrown up a few other anomalies.

The Democrats have discovered something that we consider perhaps a serious breach of due process. I am advised that Drake International, which, of the private tenderers, received the most lucrative contract, has strong links with the former leader of the Liberal Party, Dr John Hewson. I am advised that Drake International has as its managing director a Robert W. Pollock, who was also the top executive of ABN Amro Holdings, a company listed as the global ultimate name of Drake International Inc. This company is also the principal shareholder of ABN Australia Ltd, which lists Dr Hewson as its chairman.

What we are asking for, Senator Tierney, is an explanation from the government as to the links between the receipt of this contract worth millions of dollars and the former leader of the government's party.

talk.start.para: —You've been taking lessons from Senator Faulkner.
—Order!

—We actually consider this quite a serious matter, quite a serious anomaly. When this anomaly is added to the list, part of which I have already outlined, the need for this government to justify its election process grows even more pressing. We will no longer be satisfied with vague assertions provided by the minister because his verbal assurances have been shown to be empty. The claim by his department today that our concerns and those of the community at large are `irrelevant nonsense' just add to the growing body of evidence that this government, far from demonstrating any real commitment to addressing the unemployment problem, chooses instead to show its contempt for the people who are hurting the most from its reforms.

speech.para: There have been a number of comments made here today about the difficulty of addressing the unemployment issue. Nobody fails to accept that that difficulty exists but I do find it very hard to take when someone like Senator Synon stands up and says that her government has implemented new and innovative measures. Far from it. We have seen a return to some of the oldest and most antiquated, outdated measures in the book. When a government legislates for a compulsory work for the dole program, it even legislates the word `dole'. For the first time so far as I know—not only in the history of this nation but perhaps internationally, as senators may be able to advise—it legislates the word `dole'. It enshrines that in the legislation, with all its negative connotations. That is not a new response. That is not a response to what is a new problem in many respects.

Unemployment may be old but the newness is that our work force has changed. We know that traditional entry level jobs, especially those occupied by young people, have disappeared. Our work force has been fundamentally restructured, and people have to accept that. That is where labour market programs come in. That is where we accept that skills and training and access to education at all levels is mandatory. It is necessary to ensure that people do have the skills with which they can compete in a work force and, increasingly, a global work force. As for these new ideas, I cannot see any forthcoming from the government.

To make one final point, when I talk about stereotypes surrounding the word `dole', Senator Synon in her contribution could not leave it alone. She could not resist the chance to perpetuate some of the negative stereotypes that we hear about young people. I swear that I get so sick and tired of the dole bludgeoning that goes on in this place by some decision makers and some members of parliament who find it much easier to use young unemployed people as scapegoats for the fact that their failed, miserable, outdated policies to solve unemployment in this country are just not working.

talk.start.para: —There are many points that need to be taken up in this very important debate brought into this place by my colleagues Senator Carr and Senator Mackay. The first point I want to take issue with is Senator Synon's claim that the tender process for the new employment agencies is all above board and par for the course, that it has been followed completely according to procedure, and that it should be ticked off by an independent assessor. We have had questions in this place about a Mr Khadar Roude, a person who has actually been approved—for a significant number of dollars—to assist with the employment placement of unemployed people. That man has no office, no facilities, no staff, no anything.
—No phone.
—Yes, no phone.
—Can't you find anything but this? You keep re-running this. The guy is setting up a small business, you should welcome that.

—One would have to say, on the evidence of just that one, you would hope the department, let alone the assessor, would be very concerned about what could have possibly gone wrong. Just a soupcon of doubt would have helped, Senator Tierney.
—How can you condemn him before he even starts work?

—Because there are clear examples of that sort—and more than just one—across the nation that makes this side of the house, the Labor Party, very concerned about the process. Nobody would be more appreciative than I if they got it right. You, in the corridors of power and in the rooms of your colleagues in the ministry, are concerned too; you know how bad this looks. You know that some of you have gone, before the Labor Party has got there, to raise concerns about the process—and properly you should raise those concerns.

speech.para: What everybody in this place is united about, surprisingly, is that we would like to see every Australian who wants a job to be able to get one and to work. That is what we know Australians want. There is no doubt at all that any figures that show there is increased employment should be accepted with the celebration that that means, though—as I will go on to do—those figures need to be very closely examined to see whether they tell the whole truth or just a sort of truth.

First of all, let us be concerned that you, in turfing out the old order for assisting with employment and replacing it with a new one, do not have the comfort and the assurance that the process you have gone through is entirely successful or satisfactory. More than most in this place, Senator Tierney, you know that. I believe that is going to be a matter of major concern and that we will need to keep a very close eye on precious taxpayers' dollars that may already be pouring down the gurgler. They will not be assisting people get jobs.

talk.start.para: —You wasted $1.7 billion on Working Nation.
—Senator Tierney, that is the next point that I wish to come to. You know full well—and I can hear you saying it now—that you have to give these things time to work.
—Over two years we found out what happened with Working Nation.
—The Working Nation program was in place and was beginning to bite. As any number of people would say, in the analysis of that program—
—Two-thirds back on the dole queue!

—Yes, clearly there were some bits that were not as good as others and there were bits that were hugely successful. You did, with a stroke of the pen, a $1.8 billion slice through the whole lot and it has gone—the good along with the not so good.
—There was a lot of not so good.
—It was never given time to make an effect. You should be very cautious about your own programs, Senator.
—Tell us about your new work opportunities.

—You should be the first down there arguing that any tender process that is ticked off and that allows a person with absolutely no infrastructure at all to be granted a very large amount—I believe $1 million—to assist unemployed people to get jobs is a joke; a sick expensive joke at the taxpayers' expense. For any people who are looking for jobs we should hang a sign out that says `Don't go there'. They will find that out themselves very quickly.
—How do you know that? You are smearing people in this place. He hasn't even started yet.

—I want to pick up on the very important points raised by my colleague Senator Mackay, which were also picked up on by Senator Stott Despoja—that is, if you are not on benefits you are not going to be given the sort of assistance you need. Before I come to that—and I will come round to it again, I hope—I want to pick up on why I am concerned about these unemployment figures. While I am very glad that they are down, I am concerned that they are masking a large number of people who are now so discouraged they are no longer being counted.
—Tell us about your record over 13 years. What was your average over 13 years? Eight and a half per cent over 13 years.
—Order! Senator Tierney!

—You should listen to this, Senator Tierney, because for all the years we were in government more and more women in this country exercised their options to go out to work to earn money to assist their families, to assist their children into education because they saw the value of it. They picked up on our government's program to move retention rates from 37 per cent to over 80 per cent in our years in government. You, Senator Tierney, with your interest in education, ought be barracking for that because it was a brilliant success. Those women who went out there to work to assist their families—
—You didn't have anything to do with it. They did it in spite of your government, not because of it.

—It is funny how the story changes post election, isn't it, Senator? Those women went to work, and they were able to do that because they were backed up by a government committed to and insisting on seeing they had the support—for example, child care. An article in the Herald Sun of Tuesday 10 March, entitled `Women give up on the hunt for work', shows that women are giving up. They are one group of the discouraged jobseekers. They are one group that no longer have that high participation rate which made it so difficult for the figures to come down for the Labor Party when it was in government. But it certainly meant that many people enjoyed the opportunity of working in this country. As David Luff writes:

speech.para: Almost 120,000 job-seekers, mostly women, stopped looking for work last year believing there was no hope of finding a job.
But the Federal Government yesterday chose to ignore the figures, preferring to concentrate on a rebound in job advertisements last month.
About 3.7 million adults were not working compared with the 9.2 million people in the labour force . . .
About 1.2 million said they were not actively looking for work or not available for it even though more than half wanted work.
The number of discouraged job-seekers—people not doing anything to find work and people not receiving unemployment benefits—stood at 118,400, with women accounting for two-thirds.

This is one of the things that is not obvious in those figures but is a critical part of the story that needs to be told. Whatever else we do, we ought be telling the truth here; we ought be telling the whole story, the complete story. We should be aware of how many people are discouraged and not being counted any more. Women are very high in that category.

You have had a policy since you came into office of encouraging women out of the work force because you know that is one way in which you can drop the figure for unemployment, and it is beginning to happen. It is happening, in particular, because of another mean-spirited decision by your leader to take away the operational subsidy for community-based child-care centres and to peg the assistance as the fees rose. In most centres those fees have gone up about $20 per week per child and many families cannot afford it any more. Women who use child care are now dropping out of the work force. Those women are not able to be counted here. They have given up; they are discouraged.

There is another group of people associated with child care whom you do not count. I heard yesterday—though I always qualify these figures as to whether they are exactly the latest and most accurate—that 48 community-based child-care centres around this country have now closed under your government. If you allow an average of 10 women working in each child-care centre, that is 480 women who are on the unemployment list because of your policies to see the closure of community-based child-care centres. It is not only the families who use child care, but it is also the workers who provide the child care. They are not counted in your list. They are discouraged. They are not out there either.

There is another very important group that is not being counted. These are the people who are 55. We have got a lulu of a challenge for them: if they want to be on unemployment benefits, they have to run down any savings, in particular superannuation. I wonder why, if you became unemployed at 55, you would want to say, `Right, that's it; I'm out of work for the rest of my life. Nobody will take me on. I might as well give up now.'

Most people at that age expect and hope that they will be able to come back into the work force and would prefer, as they could in the past, to go on to unemployment benefits and seek further employment. These days, if they do that they are going to be eligible for unemployment benefits only if they run down their superannuation and retirement benefits, so many of them shrug their shoulders and become retired so they can actually have access to and maintain the nest egg they have worked all their lives for. They are not counted anymore. They are off the list. That is a very interesting little way in which you score how many people are unemployed.

That goes for the 55s who are now retired so as to save the nest egg that so many of them have been working 20 or 30 years for—taxpayers of this country putting their pennyworth in and saving for their retirement now being forced to retire at 55 if they want to have full access to it. You are a mean lot over there, a mean, nasty lot.

What is interesting is, this is the government that said it would be the government to make people's lives comfortable and relaxed. Any time you go into the community that is not what they tell you. I heard one of my Liberal colleagues saying the other day that you should not worry too much about unemployment in Canberra and about all those public servants who have lost their jobs because over a year and a half or so almost all of them will have got some other employment—as though that has fixed that.

Have they ever stopped to speak to somebody who has lost their job? Do they understand what lack of confidence, what kind of anxiety and what kind of pressure that builds on their families and that, when these people finally do get another job, they are actually not the same kind of assured and capable people they were before they lost their jobs? It is as if there is a transition with no measurement of the gap, no measurement of the pain and suffering, no measure of the loss of income and no measure of the anxiety—and that is the word I keep hearing in the community. `We're not sure where we will be, Senator.' `We're not sure we will still have a job.' `We're not sure that we will be able to keep on paying for the mortgage or the borrowings.' You know that.

Senator Natasha Stott Despoja also talked about the increasing and dramatic casualisation of jobs and the move to contracts—12-month contracts in particular for many people. Senator Tierney and I are in the process of concluding an inquiry into the status of teachers in this country. One of the things that was raised with us time and time again was the difficulty of being a first year graduate teacher, if you are lucky to score a 12-month contract to become a teacher. You know and I know—and they certainly told us this in bucketloads of evidence before the committee—that a 12-month contract is no way to move into your new profession with some kind of optimism that this year you will be really learning as you go, but that will be all right because the year after and the year after that you will be able to build on and improve those skills.

No, what they say is, `We are very concerned about whether we will even have a job as a teacher in 12 months time.' Worse than that, many of the people who would be a mentor for those young teachers have been saying, `It is hard to get too enthusiastic for a young teacher who may not be there next year and who may not even be a teacher at all next year.' It is a double if not a triple whammy. That is the impact of these short-term contracts, as just one example from the comprehensive evidence we have taken over the last few months of the negative impact of that.

Many of those people may be counted as employed this year but they do not have any confidence that they will be employed for the longer term. They are the sorts of people who are frightened to get into major investment. The figures show there has been a very significant drop in confidence not only in the business community but among the purchasers of this world. We saw those figures just the other day—I notice Senator Synon was not quoting those at us today—a massive drop in business confidence and consumer confidence, and I have just stated one of the reasons.

Even the people in the work force do not have the confidence they will be there with any long-term prospects; they are anxious about the on-going security or income that they can expect. It is more so if they are in casual work. We saw this, too, all through the evidence brought before child care inquiries; not only from the child care point of view but from the the viewpoint of families and particularly women who are working casually Monday, Tuesday this week and Thursday, Friday next week.

How on earth are they going to manage their lives on that? The difficulty of those rotating hours are tough enough; the casualisation and the lack of security about even being able to have to rearrange your life in a couple of months is also pressurising those people. The stress and anxiety builds up and more and more those women, in particular, are retreating from the work force. They are discouraged; they are not counted.

I would urge a caution about wild celebration of today's figures. We know that what they reflect is a very significant drop in the participation rate of women. You know it, and what is more you cannot actually boast it because it would make clear your unspoken agenda to remove women from the work force. I have been saying this for two years. I was laughed at when I first said it; slowly the picture becomes patently clear. There is no denying it. They are out of the work force, they are discouraged from looking for work and now they are not even being counted. You cannot acknowledge it because, first, as I say, it would indicate your mean, miserable, limited, mean spirited agenda and, secondly, you would have to acknowledge the success we had in our term in a large part of our government—
Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Oh, laugh. We had a huge participation rate.
—And a huge unemployment rate—8½ per cent average over 13 years.
—No, for a brief time, Senator. Nobody more than this Labor government hurt about that. There was no boasting about it, Senator. There was a great regret.
—Are you going to support Mrs Scott in Oxley?

—Senator Mackay reminds me of one of your colleagues from Queensland, Senator Ian Macdonald, who reckons—of course, I would never use such language—that the best place for women is `barefoot, pregnant and in the kitchen'. You remember him, don't you? And you remem ber Senator Newman who said last year in answer to a question from Senator Ray, I think it was, that if women behaved like the Defence Department did in being wasteful it would be right for her husband to push her out of the home. We know the Lyons Forum's approach to women. We know what some of your colleagues have said on the record. We know the problem you have about women who are not at home looking after children. You have never really celebrated it, and here it is: women are out of the work force. Women are not being counted because they are discouraged. You have cut back child-care centres. The work force is reduced by those 480 to 500 women who do not have their jobs any more. There are all those thousands of families who can no longer go to work or participate because they do not have access to the wide distribution of quality child-care services that were instituted under our government.

speech.para: Those are the major points that I wished to raise in my contribution to this debate. The points raised by Senator Synon have been more than dealt with; particularly her point about the tender process. I do believe that you should be very cautious about the success of that. You can be assured that we will be watching very closely. Senator Synon said that all the unemployed people would have touch screen services. That will be the thrill of their lives. What people want when they are looking for a job is somebody to talk to. It is nice to know, as a first stop, where you might be able to find a job but they are not going to find full satisfaction and assistance from touch screen services. What is this? An up market way of reading the newspaper? If the list of job vacancies is improved, then that is a good thing.

Your proposals for helping people get jobs are really scandalous, particularly the proposal that if you are not on an unemployment benefit you are not going to be eligible for that kind of assistance. Your claims have been refuted very comprehensively by Senator Mackay. They have been refuted again by Senator Natasha Stott Despoja. Unemployment remains a major concern. We are seeing many people discouraged, defeated and retreating from the work force. They are no longer counted. Be careful of your figures.

talk.start.para: —I would like to start by congratulating Senator Mackay for raising a serious issue—unemployment. We have spent several days in this parliament listening to issues that do not concern this nation. We have spent several days muckraking because of this policy vacuum in the ALP—these policy airheads on the other side who have absolutely nothing to say on the issues that concern this nation, and the most important is unemployment. We have been on this debate now for 1½ hours. Has anyone in this chamber or anywhere else heard in that debate an original idea from the other side, from Senator Mackay or Senator Crowley or any of the other apologists for their failure for 13 years to do anything about this problem?

speech.para: Their failure is shown up by the fact that, on average, unemployment over 13 years was 8½ per cent. That is their brilliant record. And that is only the official rate; it does not include the underemployed—the part-time people who wanted a full-time job and could not get it. It did not include the ones who had given up altogether. Senator Crowley was talking about the participation rate. Of course there were a lot of people who were not participating who would have liked to. To put them all in, the evidence from the long-term unemployment inquiry that I chaired three years ago was that you have to roughly double your rate. So your record over 13 years was about 17 per cent unemployment in reality in this nation.

Don't let us start on youth unemployment. If you go to your figure it becomes horrendous. You left government with 29 per cent youth unemployment. I remember reading in a book in 1985 about the terrible state of youth unemployment in this country—25 per cent in 1985. You were in government for 11 years beyond that and what happened to it? It went from 25 per cent up to 29 per cent. What a great record. And Senator Mackay comes in here today and raises the issue of unemployment—after 13 years of miserable failure. What did we hear from the Labor Party? Did we hear a grand plan for solving this problem? I do not think anyone in this chamber on this side did. We were all straining and listening for solutions from the ALP to unemployment in this country.

What are your options? Are you going to continue with our program? From what you are saying today, probably not. Are you going to go back to the failed Working Nation program, where you wasted $1.7 billion, where your placement rate was one-third? You took the others, the two-thirds left, all those hundreds of thousands of people, trained them and there was no job; trained them, no job. Are you going to do that? Is that your option? There is a third option, isn't there? There is a grand new vision of the ALP for unemployment in this country. Well, where is it? We have had in this chamber all your shadow ministers and your leader here going on for days on issues that are irrelevant to the people of Australia. I looked up into the gallery today and saw all those people looking down as you were just muckraking, destroying people's reputations, and they must go away thinking, `What on earth is happening to this country if these people have anything to do with the running of the country?' You are not focusing on the serious issue.

Congratulations, Senator Mackay, here you have actually returned to the serious issue, but you are a bit on the back foot with it, given 13 years of failure. You are also on the back foot because of the record of this government over the last two years. When we came into power, unemployment in this country was 8.7 per cent. It is now, on today's figure, 8.1 per cent. That is a steady drop over that time. You obviously put up this motion this morning on the basis that the unemployment record was going to be bad. Well, didn't you get sprung.

talk.start.para: —No.
—Did you know before everybody else? You really got caught because it showed the success of the government policies continuing and the continuing decline in unemployment in this country.

speech.para: Senator Synon has already indicated the success of the Howard government program. Let me take you quickly through some of that success. There has been a 2½ per cent drop in interest rates.

talk.start.para: —What about growth—what's the growth rate?

—You mentioned growth. Growth is the highest of all OECD countries at 3½ per cent. What was your average over 13 years? Two per cent was your average, and we have nearly doubled that since we have got into government. You had this great plan that you were going to get unemployment down to five per cent. What a joke. With the policies that you had brought in, you were never going to get anywhere near that, particularly when you had the budget deficits that you were running.

speech.para: What this government has done has saved Australia from the disaster you were leading it towards. Just imagine with the Asian economic meltdown if we had continued over the past two years with the failure of your government. Where would Kim Beazley's $10.5 billion be now under your policies? Would it be $12 billion last year and $14 billion this year? Do you think that is unrealistic? I remember the 1992 deficit being over $19 billion. You are capable of these big numbers, and under your government it would have continued. As we move into this Asian meltdown, what it is showing is the strength of the Australian economy under the policies of this government.

talk.start.para: —What's the foreign debt? You don't mention that, do you?

—You can bark away over there, Senator, but it will not change the reality. Today's figures prove that those very sound policies in what it has done with the budget and what it has done with interest rates have set the business climate to actually reduce unemployment. So there is your secret. It is not going back to your failed Working Nation policies; the secret is to set the policies in such a way that you actually get unemployment coming down. Does it work? Look at what has happened over the last two years: 8.7 per cent down to 8.1 per cent sounds like a success to me. The policies of this government are working.

speech.para: Let us look back at some of the failure of your record. I do not think we can emphasise these points too strongly. We need to keep telling the Australian public again and again about the way you failed over 13 years. The one who really leapt to your defence today, greatly to my amazement, was Senator Stott Despoja, who started quoting international conventions; incorrectly, as it turns out. She was claiming that under the 1949 ILO convention you had to provide public providers for the unemployed. She was actually mixing up `publicly provided' and `public provided'. It does not necessarily have to be run by the government but it has to be public and open. She was confusing those terms and trying to mislead the Senate into thinking that we are breaking some ILO convention. We are not.

She also went on to defend the CES. What a brave senator, defending the record of the CES. What was the success rate of the CES, the centrepin of the previous government's unemployment policies? Didn't they do well. It was 20 per cent. There are the jobs up on the board: go and have a look and go out and find one. It was just not a successful approach. Moving into case management was a good move. We have always supported that. Moving on to what we are doing now is even more successful. I think Senator Stott Despoja should perhaps come back sometime and acknowledge that.

I said I was going to remind the Senate of the record under the last Labor government. If we go back and look at what happened to the long-term unemployed, we see that the Labor government really tried to put a lot of effort in and put a lot of money in. That is what it was all about, putting in money and being showy. Calling something Working Nation: what a joke, calling it Working Nation. What irony. What an insult to the unemployed, making out that, if you institute such a program, people are actually going to be working. We know that after the program, with $1.7 billion down the drain, two-thirds of them were not working at all.

As a matter of fact, Wollongong, under Working Nation at its height, had a very famous visitor, Kim Beazley. He went and spoke to the youth of Wollongong—a very brave man for doing that, I thought. It was publicised and it was televised nationally. Kim Beazley was up there saying, `We have got these training programs for you to get work.' The audience replied with one voice, `But there are no jobs.' What they said in Wollongong at that time was that they had the best trained dole queues in the world. They get into a training program and try to find a job—no job. Another training program, try to find a job—no job. Then another training program. The best trained dole queues in the world.

That was what the fault of Working Nation was; it was assuming that if you trained people there would be jobs around. The whole thing failed. What we have instituted with the economic policies that I mentioned before is an approach that actually creates real long-term jobs.
The disillusionment with the former Working Nation program was brought home very starkly to our committee that was inquiring into long-term unemployment. I quote from one of the unemployed, who said:
It is more comfortable to remain lying in the gutter than to be picked up and dropped back in it again.

That is what he said. That is what happened to him. They picked him up and gave him some training, but there was no job so he was back where he was before. He found that a shattering and disheartening experience. As we went around the nation we found the phase of this program was just a matter of churning people in the dole queue. What we really should look at are the outcomes of this program.

What was the employment growth in full employment under Working Nation and under the Labor government in its last years? Between 1991 and 1995 there were 6,000 net new full-time jobs. What happened in the recession was a collapse in full-time jobs. We came out of the recession and full-time jobs started to increase again, but if you look over those four years, the great achievement of the Keating government was the creation of 6,000 new jobs—net. What a disgraceful record. With $1.7 billion that was the outcome. That is why, in March 1996, two years ago, you were tossed out in such a devastating way. It was because of the failure of a whole range of programs but, in particular, programs like this one.

When we look at the fine grain of the programs under Working Nation we see that the story gets worse. Senator Mackay did say that some of the programs worked particularly well and I am sure some of them did. But there were appalling examples of failure and waste. Probably one of the worst was `new work opportunities'—$170,000, on average, per successful placement. Money was pumped into this right until the federal election, particularly up in my area. The member for Paterson, Bob Baldwin, and I went out to a graduation ceremony for one of these groups. They had been working for six months in this new work opportunities program. Bob Baldwin asked them at the end, `Hands up those who have found a job after this scheme.' Out of the 25 people in the program, one hand went up. That was a terrible failure. It was very disillusioning for the people involved and it was a terrible waste of government money.

What we have done is move away from that sort of program. California based research looked at how those Working Nation type programs were operating in one county and compared them to another county where work for the dole type programs were operating. What they found in that research was that the work for the dole type program was working better because you were putting people straight into work. Instead of training where there are no jobs you put them into work, they build up the confidence and they get new skills. When they compared the two groups at the end of this time they found that the people who were in the work for the dole type programs were more likely to go on to training or more likely to find work.

We have had a very successful initial start to this pilot. The party opposite opposed it fiercely, set up an inquiry and came down against it, and then suddenly did a backflip when they discovered that the vast majority of the public out there supported it, seeing it as something very necessary and something that would give young people hope. For that reason, this government is expanding this program.

The people opposite today have spent a lot of time doing some sort of analysis of the new programs we have adopted. They have gone on from work for the dole to Job Network, spending a lot of time spreading gloom and doom, saying that terrible things are happening under Job Network. It is funny that they keep bringing up this example in western Sydney.

talk.start.para: —We don't think it's funny.

—In this chamber and also up in the estimates I think I have heard this example brought up five times. It is funny that they keep bringing up this one example. Could it be because you cannot find any other examples? That is what I expect.

speech.para: Let us go back and analyse this example. Maybe this poor fellow out there, whose name you have absolutely blackened, will fail now after what you have done to him on the public record. This fellow has not even started. He cannot start until 1 May, yet you are condemning him before he starts. He has had experience in the area and he is setting up a new business. What a terrible thing to do—set up a new business! He is setting up a new business to give the unemployed in western Sydney the chance for a job. You should give him a go. You should give this program a go, because your program totally failed. This one, which has incentives in it for people to work and incentives to employ people, is one that I feel, having looked at this area very thoroughly for seven years, has a great chance of success. You should give it that chance and stop trying to condemn it before it even starts.

talk.start.para: —I rise regularly when this issue of unemployment comes up because it is an issue dear to my heart. It is an issue that should be on the table, but when Senator Tierney says that the government policies are working I do not think Senator Tierney has looked at the figures or understands what is actually going on.

speech.para: While Senator Tierney quoted the 8.7 down to 8.1, he did mention, as did others, the issue of the long-term unemployed people in this nation. Let us now look at the record and let us look at it through the ABS statistics of January 1998 on the labour force, from which we can get some comparative idea of what is really happening—not something that is fudged or fictional but something that is actual. If you look at long-term unemployment—and that is where the greatest problem is in this nation—the problem is getting those people who have been out of work for a long period of time back into the paid work force, because it is getting them back into the paid work force that will give them dignity.

If one looks at the table headed `Long-term unemployment', which is table 26 at page 33 of the ABS labour force survey, January 1998, one sees what is happening in reality to the long-term unemployed people. It is worthwhile to compare what has happened from December 1996 to December 1997. If one looks at the seasonally adjusted figures, one will see that there has been a change in that period of time for people who were unemployed for between 52 weeks and 104 weeks—that is, between one and two years—from 99,400 to 125,600. So what we see is a substantial increase in the number of people who were long-term unemployed between one and two years.

If what Senator Tierney and other speakers from the government said was correct, then we would be seeing their policies reducing that level, but there is now a burgeoning increase. If one looks at the long-term unemployment figures over 104 weeks—that is, two years or more—one will see that there is a slight reduction from 129,200 to 127,700. But the reason for the slight reduction is that many women who were in that area have left the job marketplace. That comes out quite clearly in the ABS statistics—that the people who have left the marketplace are women. Of course, there is an improvement in that area, but it is worse for men. You find therefore that the government's policies of trying to address long-term unemployment are not working at all; they are at the margins. They are affecting those people who are unem ployed for the under 52-week period. Whilst I am glad for anyone who gets a job, and I would applaud anyone who can find employment, the real problem that is confronting this nation is not being addressed.

If one then turns to page 34 in the same document, one finds, again, an age break-up of the unemployed persons. It is table 27, `Unemployed persons: duration of unemployment by age, marital status and full-time/part-time status, January 1998.' If one looks there—and there is no year to year comparison—one finds that there were 157,000 men who were unemployed for 12 months and over throughout this nation. However, when you go to the figures for two years and over, you find that there are 84,900. When you put it in raw statistics such as that, we are talking about a major problem.

When one looks at the figures for the females, one will find that the figure for those who were unemployed for 52 weeks and over is 81,200, and the figure for those unemployed for 104 weeks and over is 39,200. So we are seeing substantial numbers of people who, in reality, are out there unemployed, and the policies of this government have not, in any way, placed any dent in those statistics. If one looks at the collective statistics there, one finds that we have a figure for people who were unemployed for 52 weeks and over totalling 238,300 and for 104 weeks and over, 124,100. Those figures cannot be denied, and the government has to do something about it.

That was its promise to the Australian people—to do something about the evil called unemployment. These are the people who have been struggling the longest and the hardest and all we see are increasing numbers—not for the time of the previous Labor government but increasing numbers that have come about during the current term of this government. We are not talking about something that is an invention on my part; we are talking about something that is in black and white, and that shows the problem we have in this nation. I only wish that this problem would be addressed by this government and not treated in the flippant way that I believe it is on many occasions.

The second thing that I wish to address this evening is the issue of the employment services program. There are some real problems with what has happened in the tendering process for the employment services program. Senator Tierney expressed dismay that he has heard only one story, so I think it is only fair that we broaden the number of stories surrounding this issue of the granting of the tenders for the employment services program.

I am going to look at three areas. I am going to look at the area of small business—and, of course, the government claims to be the champion of small business—at community organisations where they have missed out, and also at the feelings of some of the church organisations which were equally involved in this area and have missed out.

It is interesting that the first case arises from a person whose company was unsuccessful in the tender process. I am talking about a company called About Service, which is a small business. It had nine years experience being a private provider and employed 11-plus employees. I am told that it had a placement record in the order of 65 per cent, when its direct competitors had a placement record of 40 per cent. By any test, one would think that this was a reasonable provider, an experienced provider, run by a small business operator in the area of the employment services market.

This company had high hopes in the tender process. It had experience, credibility and background in the area. If one had looked at an article in the January 1998 publication of Southern Star, a local press based in Brisbane, one would have seen that there was a little bit of hope from this company about the future. The article said:
People seeking work now have a choice of applying for jobs through a CES or private job brokerage.
Remember that this is pre the tender. The article went on to say:

About Service senior case manager Christine Polzin said the number of unemployed that the centre dealt with had trebled since the changes had been implemented with about 400 jobseekers now on its books.

The company had a track record in this area. So much so that the local federal member, the member for Griffith, Graeme McDougall, was supportive of it—understandably and rightfully so. He wrote to the principal of the company on 21 January this year in respect of the tendering process that was going on at that stage because it was emerging that the process was not necessarily kosher. He said, `The minister is aware of the problems associated with the tendering process.' So the federal member for Griffith has admitted that the government, through the minister, was aware of problems associated with the tendering process. At the end of the letter he said:
We share a joint goal, which is to place job seekers into positions which are rewarding to both the employer and the employee.
There is no doubt that there is a great deal of sincerity in supporting this small business operator within the seat of Griffith.

Let us look at the employment service record of About Service and the jobs notified over the last four weeks at About Service at their office at Browns Plains. Let us look at jobs filled over the last four weeks as opposed to jobs notified: jobs filled, 20; jobs notified, 30. Their track record is very good indeed. For the About Service Coorparoo office: jobs notified over the last four weeks, 11; jobs filled over the last four weeks, eight. Their placement record was impeccable. It was up with any of the other private service providers and community service providers in that area.

And what happened? What happened was this company failed to get anything out of the government tender process. Let me assure you: the principal of the company was definitely not a supporter of our side of politics. We are looking at a company of which 11 of its employees were affected—not one or two. It was a small business that had been built up and operated over a number of years.

I will tell you what the principals of the company had to say on 23 January in respect of the process. By this stage, there was a veil of secrecy; there was a cone of silence. Not even the Chief, 99 or 86 could find out what was going on. In the letter to me, they wrote:

Our research and our own investigations and enquiries have revealed that other companies have been offered contracts in areas where we are currently providing employment services. These companies have not been operating in our geographical location before, yet we, as an existing, established, long-term and effective provider of these services, have heard nothing.

We had a process at this stage where those who had the knowledge, the understanding and the ability were seemingly going to be denied the right to access the market that they had previously well serviced. They went on to say:
In all of our dealings relating to Government tenders over a 9 year period, we have never experienced such a situation before.
This was a small business trying to play their part out there and they were getting this treatment. It further said:

It appears that the larger organisations, and those perhaps with some political affiliations, seem to have been notified of their success first and if they decline to accept the offers submitted to them, then and only then, will other tenderers be advised and offered the leftovers.
This was a company trying to plan their future. It gets better—or worse, depending on which way you look at things. It said:

We are certainly aware that there were no guarantees of gaining acceptance of our tender, but naturally we are bewildered and confused simply due to the total lack of any formal advice regarding our tender outcome.
It went on to tell of the sort of uncertainty that has been created by the government in this process. It said:
. . . we still have 3 months left of existing contracts to fulfil and we can do nothing about this potential loss of our experienced staff.

The fear for these people was that they would lose their staff as a result of not knowing whether they were successful or unsuccessful in the tender process. Everything at that stage had led them to believe that they were unsuccessful, and ultimately they were proved to be correct. They had existing contracts which went to May that they would not be able to fulfil. It is an example of small business being attacked by this government. The letter continued:
If we have been totally unsuccessful and were advised on a fair and level playing field, this we could accept.
They could accept a fair and level playing field, but they did not feel they were in that situation. The letter continues:
We believe that what is happening currently, needs serious investigation and must be rectified immediately to remove the unnecessary uncertainty that exists.
That is, because they did not know whether or not they were going to be successful. The letter continues:

Our company will be laying off 4 of its Administration staff on Tuesday 27th January, again through no fault of their own, or that of our Company but we do need to take some pro-active measures, in anticipation, before it is too late.
Because of our excellent past track record with employment outcomes, we would find it extremely difficult, if not unbelievable, to accept that we were not successful in any way.
So there is not just one out there; there are more.
We go then to a later fax that I received from that very same company—and by this time they had some idea of the tender process outcome. The fax states:
I could not work out, now that successful tenderers have been announced, why, with the exception of Employment National, 95% of existing providers were not granted their current geographical sites.
The fax continues:
Existing small providers, like ourselves, who only contracted for their original sites and no others, are out altogether and have received no sites whatsoever—
It goes on:

In effect, what we now have is a brand new start in the employment market at the expense of the unemployed and the 1000 existing providers. This new initiative will not be totally effective for some 4 to 6 months and statistics on performance will not give a clear indication of its success or otherwise for perhaps 12 months by which time there is only 9 months of the tender period to go until it all goes to tender again. It defies logic! If the Government wanted radical change to assist the long term unemployed better, why should you opt for something like this which is so risky and unproven!
That is from a provider—a provider who had been in the industry and who had suffered the decimation of losing their business right from under their feet. The fax continues:

Every current training provider expected that Employment National would get approximately 40% of the Flex 3 tender, but of the 700 companies and community organisations that were excluded they certainly did not expect that only 200 organisations would get the rest. Let alone that most of these 200 organisations would have no previous track record at all—
None whatsoever. So the disappointment is real, and it is out there.

Just briefly, I will mention the skillshare down at Wynnum. The skillshare at Wynnum was a community based organisation. It had done a marvellous job in that area of helping the unemployed, as can be seen by the statistics alone—and I have them here: for 1989, 261; 1990, 334; 1991, 369; up to 1996-97, 310. The statistics show that this organisation was active out there in the marketplace, helping. Of course, what we will see there now, because of the demise, will be 11 jobs gone. Then you have the Catholic social response: 20 jobs gone. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I wish to make a personal explanation. I claim, under standing order 191, explanation of speeches, to have been misunderstood in this debate. May I make a brief statement?
—Yes, the honourable senator may proceed.

—Thank you. Senator Tierney in his comments has misunderstood my position and, as a consequence, his attack on it was unfounded. The Democrats do appreciate the distinction between a public provider and the public provision of services. It is disingenuous, therefore, for Senator Tierney to claim that there will be an increase in services provided under the new system simply because there will be a greater range of organisations providing them. Furthermore, I did not, at any stage, indulge or actively defend the CES, as he claimed. The Democrats, however, do support the provision of high quality, free and universal employment.
—Senator Stott Despoja, you are only able to explain how you were misrepresented, not to debate it. Have you finished?
—I will not introduce further material, interrupt or debate, as per the standing order. Thank you.

—I too join this debate on the motion now before us, which relates to industrial relations and employment policies. I think it is rather ironic that just over three to four years ago we were on the other side of the chamber leading a similar charge, if you like, trying to prove that there were better ways to deal with unemployment. But the difference between then and now is that, under the coalition government, there have been very significant improvements to the rates of unemployment. For a while, I just want to deal with that trend. So let us look at the figures.

speech.para: I do think this debate requires a little bit of balance, rather than the political point scoring that continually goes on in this place. Unemployment is a serious problem. It is something that most, if not all, Australians have been seriously touched by through their family or friends—but certainly most of us, from time to time, have been touched through our families.

We find that there has been a certain theme in unemployment going right back to the 1980s coming into 1981, before the previous Labor government got into power—it got particularly bad in 1983 when they came into power—and then we had those horrific years 1992-93-94, when it was consistently stuck at over 10 per cent and went to 11 per cent.

I believe that the difference between our approach and that of the Labor Party really and truly is one of philosophy. We believe that the best way to deal with unemployment is to make sure that we have a strong economy, successful businesses and stimulus for small business; and in time—and I think the facts are starting to prove this—job availability will go up.

I particularly want to look at this aspect—because I believe it is important. We can see that from 1994 to 1995, before we came to power, unemployment dropped from 10.5 per cent to 8.9 per cent. We can all quote figures to suit ourselves; we can take a month, we can take two months. That is not my intent.

The point I want to make here is that the drop in unemployment at that time was almost entirely due to what occurred in Western Australia after the Court government came in. Looking at the figures during that time, and anyone can analyse them very carefully, we went from having the highest level of unemployment when Carmen Lawrence was the last of a series of Labor premiers—it was at well over 11 per cent; I think it got up to 12 per cent at one stage—but, by the end of 1992 and going into 1993, Western Australia's unemployment rate had dropped to the lowest in the country. That was almost the total take-up of the jobs that were created during that time for all Australia. That was stimulated almost entirely by the opening of some great mining projects in Western Australia and getting some of the red tape out of business's way and allowing business to expand and employ people. That is what our philosophy is.

I want to work through some of these issues. I have been on inquiries and wrestled with these problems, as Senator Tierney mentioned. I wish to comment particularly on a couple of contributions made here today: firstly, that by Senator Rosemary Crowley, who referred to the very unfortunate comment, she claimed by a Liberal, about there being only one place for women—barefoot, pregnant and back in the home, or words to that effect.

Senator Crowley has not thought very hard about that. She obviously is not aware of what happened on 11 March in the other place. Apparently Janice Crosio, the member for Prospect, interjected on Minister Moylan, saying, `Go back to the kitchen.' It went a little further than that. Minister Moylan came back and spoke on indulgence—and I do not understand all the detail of the standing orders of the other place and how they operate. Mr Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, Australia's alternative Prime Minister, got himself involved. He said:
The minister is known on our side of the House as `Go back to the kitchen Moylan'.
That came from your leader. Mr Beazley also said:
That is why that was proposed. `Go back to the kitchen Moylan' is your nickname—

talk.start.para: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. This debate is not an opportunity for members of the chamber to make reflections on those in the other House. I think the senator on his feet should restrict himself to the debate at hand. Clearly he is in breach of the standing order that prevents senators making reflections.
—There is no point of order.
—The point that I was making in this very important debate is that it is pretty damn dangerous to throw stones in glasshouses because they will bounce back at you.

speech.para: Returning to the issue of reducing unemployment, regardless of what is said we know that since we came to power there has been a gradual trend downwards in unemployment—and there has been further good news today. It is not going down as fast as I or anyone on this or the other side of the chamber would like, but it has been consistent and sustained. That is important. I believe that it is going to remain consistent and sustained.

talk.start.para: —You have economic growth of below four per cent. It will not go down.
—You can rabbit on all you want but you have had your go. You are a policy-free zone over there.
—Senator Crane, direct your comments through the chair. You will get into less trouble if you do.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I will take your guidance. I must inform you that we have a policy-free zone over there. Those opposite come in here and rabbit on and carry on, but they never tell us what they are going to do. Are they going to go back to Working Nation? That is what I want to know. A week or two ago former Prime Minister Bob Hawke apologised to the Australian people for the recession that we did not have to have. There are all sorts of things we can talk about.
—So what is your objective in terms of employment levels? What is your target?
—Senator Neal, you are not helping by interjecting.

—The people over there presided over the most sustained, long-term period of unemployment in this country. We have set about endeavouring to do something about it through sound economic policy and management. Had the previous government not run up that enormous $10.3 billion deficit, we could have made even more remarkable inroads into unemployment than we have. It is my very strong view that, with sound policy and development of initiatives as the Australian accounts come back into balance, unemployment will fall even more.

speech.para: Let us look at a few of the issues which are very important in dealing with these things. One of the principal reasons we had that sustained period where unemployment ranged from nine to 11 per cent is that during the 1980s our average inflation rate was eight per cent. Today that rate is down to nearly 1.4 per cent. Business, the people who employ—small business in particular—know that they are now in a very sound inflationary position in terms of expanding their businesses and making good economic decisions which will create sustainable long-term jobs—not mickey mouse jobs.

The next point I would make relates to the impact interest rates have had—again, a very important point—and what is happening in that arena. Looking at the current situation as against that when we came into government, mortgage rates were 10.5 per cent and today they are around 6.5 per cent. For a $100,000 mortgage that is a saving of $80 a week. Taking another measure which I think is very important and will allow people to invest more and help the business community, the average mortgage is around $120,000. That represents a saving on interest rates of about $100 per week or the equivalent of a wage increase of $150 a week. It is these policies that I believe will allow Australia to be in a sound economic position to continue to, albeit slowly, make inroads into unemployment.

One of the other initiatives which is very important and which will protect Australian jobs and create them—this needs mentioning, because it did not get much coverage at the time—is our new anti-dumping measures. Those on the other side and in the other place had some 13 years to deal with anti-dumping. I have a document which I will read so that I get the facts absolutely right. It states:
Under the new arrangements interim duties can be imposed after 60 days. The time taken to reach a final finding will be reduced to 150 days and the Anti-Dumping Authority, ADA, will be abolished.

That means it will be put under one roof. That is absolutely crucial in terms of protecting Australian industry, both in dumping and in countervailing situations, from subsidised imports coming into this country. There is no doubt at all that some of the products that have come into this country have hurt Australian businesses greatly and they have created situations where there have been a job loss, a very sad and unfortunate job loss. So we are seeking, in terms of dealing with that particular issue, to get that impediment out of the way and secure Australian jobs and increase the number of Australian jobs.

I will now go through a couple of other points that I think are very important in terms of protecting Australian jobs and making sure that we get our equal share of what is available around the world, in particular in Asia. I repeat what I said in here last week: I am not one of the doomsday merchants about Asia and what has happened there. I think it is quite tragic the way some of the journalists have decided to write it up. Maybe that is a little unfair on the journalists. It is some of the commentators who talk to the journalists about the situation in Asia. At the end of the day, we are going to see two things in Asia. The first is a much stronger financial system, which is absolutely crucial to those people doing business with Asia. The other is that, although it will be a slower growth rate, it will still be in the four per cent to seven per cent area, which will be close to leading the world as we move beyond the year 2000.

These things are all very good indicators in terms of the employment position. Australia's part in this, and I must highlight this, is our support with the IMF in terms of assisting those particular countries not through gifts, not through grants, but through loans and currency swaps, assisting them at this time through their financial difficulties. These are the types of initiatives we require in this country to sustain—and I emphasise that very strongly—the slow improvement that we are attaining as far as unemployment is concerned.

I particularly mention a little bit about training. I have my office in East Victoria Park. Parts of that electorate have some of the lowest socioeconomic areas of any electorate in Australia. It is the Swan electorate. The member is Don Randall. It was formerly held by the current Leader of the Opposition, whom I mentioned earlier. We were sick and tired, and so were the young people coming in, of the fact that they repeatedly said, `I've been trained once; I've been trained twice; I've been trained three times.' Some of them had been trained up to seven times and still did not have a job. All the training in the world will not get them anywhere unless there is sound economic policy behind it.

Having said that, I firmly believe that the more training, the more assistance and the further we can upgrade our education processes around the country, the better. It is absolutely essential that we do that. But at the end of the day there must be some hope. There is nothing more soul destroying than to be trained two or three times and still have no hope of getting a job because you have been trained in the wrong areas.
Senator Neal interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You were the absolute specialists at it. You trained them without a job at the other end. It is absolutely crucial in terms of this that the two are matched. There is a very important initiative in terms of that, and I will quote from a press release. I was going to make a little comment with regard to one component of Senator Stott Despoja's contribution today when she was critical of the work for the dole scheme. My experience with the people involved with the work for the dole scheme is that they are very proud to be able to do something in return for the assistance they are getting from the Australian taxpayer. That is my experience with the people I have talked to about it. I quote from an article today in the Advertiser . It is headed `Work for the dole scheme: a stepping stone to success. Youngsters break into the jobs world'. I will just read the first paragraph. It states:

speech.para: A north-eastern suburb's work for the dole scheme has been so successful that three of the 14 young participants building bus shelters have landed jobs within three weeks.

It then goes on to talk about the training in terms of their ability to build the bus shelters; their ability in joining, sanding, welding, design and all the various other things they are learning. That is a very good endorsement of the fact that there is a place in Australian society today for a work for the dole scheme, and that proves it. It is not the be all and end all. It is not the only answer. That is why we have introduced some flexibility into the system for people seeking jobs.

Regardless of what anybody in this place might think, not all CES offices worked as well as they might have. During that unfortunate period when we had a lot of over-45-year-olds lose their jobs, the last place they wanted to go or be seen to go, because of the psychology of it, was to a CES office. Whether we like it or not, that is a fact of life. Whether you think it is right or wrong, that is a reality. In introducing some competition, some alternatives, you are going to allow a much wider scope of people to have varying opportunities and hopefully—and I believe there will be—increased opportunities.

I want to come back to where I started in the remaining two or three minutes I have. There is no question that unemployment is a very difficult issue for Australia. It is coming down, albeit slowly. It is a very difficult problem for most Australians. As I said earlier on, they have been touched by unemployment through a partner, their family, in some instances their parents. It is very traumatic. But there is one last thing that I wish to leave in terms of this particular debate and how we can effectively assist in this process, and that is a piece of legislation that is coming up here very shortly. I refer in particular to our 10-point Wik plan and the importance of getting that legislation through this parliament. Once that is through and we can get rid of some of the deficiencies—and I am not talking about the High Court decision here; there is nothing being removed in the 10-point plan Wik legislation that was delivered by the High Court—it will get rid of some of the inventions that were created by the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, and the then Senator Gareth Evans, who is now in the other place.

The most appalling of those inventions is the right to negotiate and the way that has been handled. I heard from one of my Aboriginal friends the other day who said, `It sounds all right on the surface, but it is the overlapping claims, the extortion, the fact that whoever happens to negotiate gets all the money, buys their four-wheel drive vehicle and then skips town.' I am sure Senator Chris Evans over there has heard these stories in terms of what is happening on the ground. It has held up project after project throughout much of Australia, and particularly in my state of Western Australia.

There are many economic opportunities there if they are allowed to be opened up and developed. The 10-point plan is part of doing that. It will increase the opportunities for jobs; it will increase exploration, mining and exports—these are the things work will come from. Finally, it is also absolutely crucial in terms of investment on an existing property that we get certainty back into title. This issue exists and has made a lot of people very cautious about what they do at this particular time as far as their investment and expansion are concerned. Where titles for exclusive possession have been granted, that should be made absolutely crystal clear in the legislation. We should get rid of this nonsense of claims over private land and claims over land where exclusive possession has been granted.

talk.start.para: —I wish to make a couple of quick points in the five minutes available to me in this general business debate. I am pleased to join the debate because it is about an issue that is crucial to the future of this country. I want to say that I think it is important that we stress what has happened in terms of the new employment services market that the government has sought to establish. The point I want to stress is that the government introduced a bill into this parliament last year to set the framework for the new market that they hoped to establish. That bill was debated and passed by the House of Representatives and was then debated in the Senate.

speech.para: But before the debate in the Senate had finished, the government withdrew the bill. The government was not prepared to accept the amendments already passed by the Senate and, rather than allow the Senate to complete its work and review what had occurred and take on board the opinions of the other senators in this chamber, it essentially spat the dummy, withdrew the bill and said, `We don't need you. We can set up our new employment services market without you; therefore, we're not going to accept any amendments, any criticism, any critique, any improvements to this bill.'

I want to make it very clear to those listening and put on the record that the government will wear this market. The government established this market without parliamentary approval and without accepting the parliamentary processes in shaping that market. We made a range of criticisms about the government's proposal. We accepted in principle the move to a more competitive market. It reflected a development that had started under the previous Labor administration of allowing private companies to be involved in the employment market. But we had a range of concerns about the new market arrangements, about how it treated the long-term unemployed, about the role of what is now the old CES and very important issues that went to privacy and freedom of information concerns—a whole range very serious public policy issues.

The government would not accept the scrutiny of the parliament. The government said, `No. We want to do it our way; we won't accept any parliamentary scrutiny.' So it withdrew the bills and proceeded down this path of establishing a new employment service market in a quite reckless manner. At the time, this was in the hands of Senator Vanstone, who was the minister at the time. But I understand that it was driven straight out of the Prime Minister's office. She took her instructions from the Prime Minister's office. They had reimposed learner's plates on her office and her activities as the minister then, and they deliberately decided, straight from the Prime Minister's office, that they would go without any parliamentary processes into this new employment services market.

The government will have to wear this grand experiment because the parliament was not given the opportunity to scrutinise the bill as it was. It was not given the chance to debate the issues pertaining to this new employment services market.
