The criticisms that will come home to roost must be worn and accepted by the government and the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) because they refused to have any parliamentary input into this market. I want to make that very clear. At the moment it may not seem such an important point but, when this whole thing unravels, I think Dr Kemp in the other House and Senator Ellison in this chamber are going to have to wear the responsibility for what will be a gigantic failure, a real let-down of unemployed people and something that will lose the Commonwealth millions of dollars because the whole thing is a shambles.

The new employment services market has been organised without parliamentary approval. It was foisted upon a department that has had its staffing and leadership culled so that it is not in a position to undertake this sort of experimental development. I think we face a real disaster that will reflect, firstly, on the unemployed people in this country and will have much wider ramifications as well.

The other point I want to make is that there are serious legal concerns about this market because of the lack of parliamentary legislation underpinning it. I think the whole thing will collapse under legal challenge. I think the government will be severely embarrassed when this whole thing crumbles. In the couple of seconds left to me, I seek leave on behalf of Senator Denman to have her speech in corporated in Hansard. It has been checked with the other side.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
Senate Speech—11th March 1998
I wish to rise and speak in particular on the issue of the difficulties faced in the region in which I live in getting unemployment down.

I want to speak generally with regard to Tasmania and a little more specifically at times, of the Mersey-Lyell statistical division which includes a lot of the West and North West Coasts and includes the cities and towns of Burnie, Devonport, Zeehan, Queenstown and Strahan.

I mention the Mersey-Lyell region because that has the highest unemployment rate in Tasmania. In the last labour force data released in March 1998 the unemployment rate was 15.1 per cent representing 8500 unemployed while Tasmania's rate was 12 .5 per cent. So there is a significant difference in the North West & West Coast figures compared to the rest of the State.

It was revealed this week that seasonally adjusted job advertisements for Tasmania fell 8.6 per cent opposed to a national increase of 5.1 per cent. With the release of those figures there was also some positive news that the underlying trend for Tasmania was for slow continued growth.

Unfortunately the rate of growth is too slow and not fast enough to offset contraction in the areas such as engineering and paper making to industries that are located on the North West Coast. As an example those areas are struggling to compete or to have had significant decrease in demand because of factors such as the Asian meltdown or the fall in the global price of gold.
It is important to realise that I do not believe our Tasmanian businesses as a whole are inefficiently managed.

I believe, from discussion with many in the Tasmanian business community, that we are equal to our mainland counterparts in capturing markets in an increasing competitive market. Many Tasmanian businesses have had to remain lean and mean because of our geographical isolation. We have for example some very competitive building contractors who are constantly winning tenders in Melbourne and Sydney.
It's not surprising that Tasmania is in a prolonged recession.
Tasmania has lost in the order of $160 million from the State economy since the Federal Liberal Government took power.
It is difficult to reconcile that loss of revenue with the comments of the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, when he said he was committed to looking after the special needs of Tasmania.
This shortage of money has not assisted in what is the most critical issue for the nation and for Tasmania that of unemployment.
Tasmania is not benefiting from this crusade by the Federal Government to balance the books.

Not only has the State Government had costs shifted to it by the Commonwealth without the compensation in return but it is the individual Tasmanian who has been personally stung. Be it by a decreasing of benefits or increasing of costs or even by the decreasing level of service provided by their local community funded organisation.
Those individual increases in costs includes things like increased child care charges, increased individual contributions for legal aid, and increased nursing home fees.
As we know Tasmania does rely heavily on federal grants with 53 per cent of all Tasmanian public sector income being provided in the way of federal grants.

With this cost shifting as part of the deficit reduction strategy there has not been, in my view an adequate reciprocation of the obligation by the federal government to reduce proactively and urgently the high levels of unemployment that is crippling Tasmania.
There has been a neglecting in my view of introducing positive measures that could assist Tasmania.
Especially when some traditional areas within the economy are significantly without those holes in the economy being adequately filled by those growth areas.

In saying that Tasmania, has had, some recent successes over the last decade that have flown in the face of a slowing and stagnant economy such as our seafood industry. I have a very high regard for the entrepreneurialism of Tasmanian business men and women that have led to those successes, such as our vibrant seafood industry.
I just don't believe this Federal Liberal Government even recognises the extent of the unemployment problem in Tasmania.
Tasmania is experiencing poor economic growth, but I do not believe that Tasmania's economic structure is any worse than some of the Mainland states.
In saying that I also believe Tasmania has some unique problems that impede our aim to possess an expanding economy.
Tasmanians are being told that benefits will accrue, once all the reforms are in place in the areas such as competition, the financial system, industry policy and industrial relations.

What's hard for the unemployed of Tasmania to stomach is that the economic and industrial reforms agenda being followed by the Federal Government may to some degree lead to a raising in productivity and living standards in the Mainland cities but that they and the rest of regional rural Australia suffers.
Now is the time for the Federal Government to reciprocate in providing greater levels of direct public investment with a full engagement of local government and regional bodies to select projects.

I do not believe that a program of infrastructure should have to be of national significance but rather should have clearly defined objectives that are linked solely to Tasmania and tackles unemployment.

I have received a letter recently as no doubt all my Tasmanian colleagues have received from The Master Builders' Association of Tasmania regarding an infrastructure project seeking funding under the Federation Fund. It is for an AFL stadium. I understand very well the significance of such a project to the building industry but do not believe with all the political involvement in the decision making process that such a project has on the face of it a demonstrated capability to be a balanced, sustainable development.

That is probably a harsh view because the aim of the fund is to generate employment and stimulate development in the lead-up to the centenary celebrations of federation. The building of such a stadium would probably do that but then how can we be assured that it will generate employment once it is established and especially soak up those unemployed in the Mersey-Lyell region.

There is certainly a strong sentiment in the North West of the State that an infrastructure project of such magnitude like an ALP Stadium deserves to be located in the region with the highest unemployment rate.

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 5 March 1998, on motion by Senator McKiernan:

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak today on the report from the Senate's Legal and Constitutional References Committee into sexuality discrimination which was tabled in this place on 2 December last year. I was not able at that time to speak at length because of the pressure of business at that time of year.

speech.para: I would like to start by using the words of another and more famous Democrat, former US Attorney-General Robert Kennedy. In 1966, he spoke the following words that have been frequently quoted, reminding us that:

Each time someone stands up for an ideal, or acts to improve the lot of others, or strikes out against injustice, he sends forth a tiny ripple of hope and crossing each other from a million different centres of energy and daring, those ripples build a current that can sweep down the mightiest walls of oppression and resistance.

I hope this report is part of those ripples and that current that will help reduce and remove the oppression that currently exists in the Australian community. I address this report as the Australian Democrat spokesperson on sexuality and transgender issues. It has responsibility for the piece of legislation that was the central focus of this committee report. I hope to see that legislation debated in the Senate at some stage soon to build on the good work that this committee did and that this report does.

As a political party, the Democrats have been pro-active in championing the rights of lesbian and gay Australians since our inception in 1977. The very first branch meeting of our party was held in the lounge room of Christopher Byron Carter—an openly gay man who was also a founding member of the party and who later served on the staff of former Senator Don Chipp and someone who has a strong legacy in the Democrats.

It is important to remember that 1977 was only 21 years ago, but Australia was a very different place in lots of ways. With the exception of South Australia, at that time, consensual same sex activity was a criminal offence in every state and territory of this nation. Prosecutions were relatively common as was the regular pastime of police randomly raiding gay and lesbian social venues and blackmail, humiliation and intimidation of patrons was a common occurrence.

It is important for the Senate to note that within the last 15 years in some places we are still imprisoning mainly gay men for being simply who they are. It took the riots at the first Mardi Gras in 1978 to set gay law reform firmly on the political agenda in Australia. I acknowledge the hard work and dedication of activists everywhere in pursuing reform. I was very proud to be part of the very large and enthusiastic Democrat contingent that helped commemorate the 20th anniversary of that civil rights movement with 700,000 other people in Sydney on 28 February this year.

Regardless of the reforms and the advances that have been made in the last 20 years, complacency is certainly not warranted, as this report so strongly indicates. As recently as August 1994, Victorian police raided the Commerce Club in Melbourne—a well-known gay and lesbian night club—and unlawfully strip searched 463 of its patrons. To our great shame, the Tasmanian parliament only decriminalised same sex activity last year, with the Western Australian parliament still to catch up with the rest of the country. It still remains the fact that your human rights will be different if your are lesbian, gay or transgender depending on where you live in this country. I would like to take the opportunity to mention the work of my state colleague the Hon. Helen Hodgson MLC, who has introduced decriminalisation and anti-discrimination measures in Western Australia.

If Australia is to retain its rightful place amongst the community of nations as a country which promotes human rights, then we must do so in a clear, unambiguous and universal way. Amnesty International has documented the international position in their publication Breaking the silence last year by illustrating that torture and political imprisonment are not uncommon in many countries of the world simply on the grounds of sexuality.

It remains a source of some puzzlement to me that some people are perfectly comfortable with the notion of anti-discrimination on the grounds of race, gender and disability but seem to get all up in arms when we talk about applying the same principles on the grounds of sexuality or for people who are transgendered. No doubt many senators will, like me, have been inundated in the last week or so by letters claiming that the Sexuality Discrimination Bill, which was the main focus of this inquiry, constitutes everything from an endorsement of paedophilia to a concerted attack upon religious teachings. It is clear from the tone and phrasing of these letters that a smear campaign or a misinformation campaign is under way. It is also clear that the writers of these letters have, at the very least, been told some very severe misinformation about this legislation or have failed to read or understand its contents or its scope.

One of the most important things about this inquiry, and its report, was the opportunity it gave lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people to put their case—for them to have a voice—and that is one of the great roles that Senate committees can play. Those people overwhelmingly informed the committee that their experience was one of significant disadvantage in many aspects of their daily lives. In areas of employment, more than 45 per cent of lesbians and gay men have experienced discrimination in the workplace including the loss of jobs because of their sexuality. Almost one-third report harassment in their schools and universities. One-fifth report inadequate and inappropriate medical treatment, while a staggering 70 per cent have had some experience of being verbally abused, threatened or bashed in a public place. In the Sydney area alone, over 35 men have been murdered in the past 10 or so years because their assailants thought they were gay. Clearly, this is an issue that must be addressed.

Some concern has been expressed over the inclusion of transgender people in this bill. The status of being transgendered is a medically recognised condition known as gender dysphoria. It does not include transvestitism or what is often called cross-dressing. I am sure that senators would agree that it is inappropriate and unfortunate that some people have chosen to ridicule persons who are receiving medical treatment for a medical condition, and the report recommended that the bill's aim be to protect those people who are gender dysphoric. After all, who amongst us would like to be treated the way we as a society treat gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender Australians every day of the week? The sort of treatment that those people are subjected to came out very strongly in much of the evidence that was given to the committee.

It is important to emphasise that the bill that the report addresses does not force the Christian or other religions to change their beliefs or to employ gay, lesbian or transgender people. As with other equal opportunity laws in Australia, the bill includes certain exemptions including religious organisations and churches. It does not place children at risk. It does not make unlawful acts lawful. It does not require that homosexuality be taught in schools. It does not force anyone to accept anyone else's lifestyle. It does not legitimise any specific sexual practices. It does not allow people to cross-dress in schools or at work, or allow biological men to compete in women's sport. It does, at a basic level, allow people who have been unfairly discriminated against on the basis of their sexuality or their transgender status to achieve a level of justice.

In essence, it seeks to protect all Australians, including heterosexual people, if they have been wrongfully dismissed or refused employment, accommodation or access to goods and services, or have been disadvantaged while attending or applying to educational institutions on the grounds of their sexuality. At its core this bill is basically about ensuring that all Australians are given a fair go through universal legislation common across the country to enable that to occur.

I am quite proud of the Democrats' role in this report and in the legislation that it examines. It is a serious look at the conditions faced every day by gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people in all parts of Australia. I will close by noting a 1986 statement from the Catholic church issued by the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith entitled The pastoral care of homosexual persons. It stated:

It is deplorable that homosexual persons have been and are the object of violent malice in speech or in action. Such treatment deserves condemnation from the church's pastors wherever it occurs. It reveals a kind of disregard for others which endangers the most fundamental principles of a healthy society. The intrinsic dignity of each person must always be respected in word, in action and in law.

When enacted, the sexuality and gender identity bill, which this report deals with, will implement that very important principle. I commend the report to the Senate and to the Australian public for their consideration. I know it has been a very popular report as there have been a lot of requests for copies and for information about its contents. It is a great report, and I hope everybody takes the chance to examine it.

talk.start.para: —I was intrigued by the comments we have just heard from Senator Bartlett because it seemed like he was talking about a completely different report from the one that was, in fact, handed down. To be fair to him, Senator Bartlett is new to the chamber and would not be familiar with much of the work that was done by the committee, but let me point out that the bill is principally about people who are described as transgenderists. That means they are usually cross-dressers or transvestites; that is the language that most people normally understand.

speech.para: What Senator Bartlett omitted from his very eloquent and moving speech was the fact that, in the course of the proceedings before the committee, a number of transgenderists and transgender organisations complained that they were the subject of discrimination from lesbians and homosexuals because lesbians and homosexuals refused to accept people who were cross-dressers. So I think Senator Bartlett ought to get some of his facts right when he gets up to address this matter next time, if indeed he does so.

I want to take a few minutes to address the report because it was a matter of some interest to me, and I know it is a matter of considerable interest to my constituents in Queensland. In the last two weeks my office has counted 330 letters that have been sent to me from all over Queensland complaining about the possibility that this bill could be carried. The complaints were not just about the bill. The complaints were also about the majority report of the committee, and Senator Bartlett has gilded the lily here a little bit.

Senator Bartlett says that the bill does not provide that a religious institution should be obliged to employ a transvestite, or transgenderist, in an educational institution. That is correct. The original form of the bill did require that; the then Senator Spindler withdrew that—that is correct. What Senator Bartlett did not tell the Senate—and obviously does not want my constituents to know—is that the Democrat representative and the majority Labor senators on that committee argued that, in fact, the provisions of the bill should be extended and should oblige religious schools to take on people who are transgenderists even though that is contrary to the religious foundations of that school itself.

talk.start.para: —We're not getting the whole story.

—We are not getting the whole story from Senator Bartlett. But that is what the majority of the committee argued and that is what Senator Bartlett conveniently neglected to tell this Senate. But, of course, I am not surprised.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I do not like it being implied that I am deliberately deceiving the Senate by not giving all the facts. I suggest nonetheless that Senator O'Chee does the same thing and not misrepresent the report when he is speaking to it.
—There is no point of order.

—There is absolutely no point of order as there is absolutely no point in many of the things that Senator Bartlett has to say in this place. It is just typical of the fact that the Democrats like to have their way and their say but do not like a debate. It is the hallmark of democracy, Senator Bartlett, that you can have a debate in this place. Senator Bartlett, you were listened to with considerable forbearance on this side of the chamber and I would have thought that, as a new senator, you might at least have the decency to exercise the same forbearance even though you may not agree with the arguments I put. You might at least have the forbearance to listen to them as I have listened to you. But isn't it interesting that some of the people here seem to have different standards on tolerance when it comes to points of view that they do not support.

speech.para: Let me move on to another very contentious area of this report; it relates to sport. It is very important to get the facts right here. Biologically a person who is born a man has considerable physiological advantages in most sports over women. It is to do with the fact that testosterone is produced in substantially higher quantities in a biological male than in a biological female. Everybody accepts that fact. I do not need to go into the anatomical reasons why that is so. It is just a fact.

talk.start.para: —Some more than others!

—Some more than others. That is a very helpful interjection from Senator Mackay. Senator Mackay, even women with excessively high testosterone levels do not get a testosterone level anywhere near like you would get in a man. Testosterone does a number of things. It changes the density of muscle fibre and the shape of the pelvis, for example. Another thing that it does is enhance muscle growth. If a person is born a biological male, even though they want to be a female, they cannot escape the fact that by dint of their birth they have substantial physiological advantages over women in most sports—power sports in particular, but a whole range of sports. That is why women's world records in just about any event you mention are much lower than men's world records. Men have all the physiological advantages.

speech.para: Let me give you an example. Susie O'Neill, when she won the Olympic gold medal in Atlanta in the 100 metres butterfly, did it in a time of two minutes and 9 seconds. The highest ranked Australian male in the same event—I think it was Michael Klim but it may have been Scott Miller—did it in one minute 59 seconds. He was third and there was a 10 second difference. Allowing a person who is a biological male, even though he may feel himself to be a female, to compete in female sporting events gives that person an unfair and unnatural advantage. Most people involved in sport recognise that and have condemned that part of the report that suggests that people who are transgender should be allowed to compete in sport.

I see Senator O'Brien shaking his head. He is probably under the misapprehension that the report did not say that. The report said that they should be allowed to do it. In fact, the report believed that those provisions of the bill should be applied to sport. Senator Bolkus, were he here, would say that that is not correct because there is a provision that says that a sporting organisation could apply for an exemption. They would have to apply to court for an exemption.

Senator Bolkus has also said on other instances things which were not correct. For example, he said that they have been auto matically exempted. That is not the case. The sporting body that regulates the sport would have to apply for an exemption and incur considerable legal expense to present their case and they would have to keep on doing it every five years. Sport in this country has never been well funded. Every sporting organisations will tell you that they are hard pressed for cash. Think about all those women's sporting organisations—and women's sport gets less money from sponsorship than men's sport does, and I think that that is reprehensible—going along every five years to the lawyers to kick in more money to keep applying for exemptions so that women can have a decent chance to compete against women.

talk.start.para: —Sounds like native title.
—Senator Ferris, it may create as many opportunities for lawyers as native title does. But it is unnecessary.

speech.para: The coalition senators were in the minority in this report. We said that we did not believe in discrimination and where there is violence we abhor the violence. We believe that all you have to do—and what has not been done in many circumstances—is to say that where you have a hate-motivated crime of violence the hate should be considered an aggravating circumstance. It should result in a mandatory higher penalty being imposed on the perpetrators. That is how you should deal with all hate-related crimes, be they racial, religious or sexual.

But we do not agree with the more outrageous provisions of the report and the bill and that is why I still have hundreds of constituents writing to me. If they continue to write to me and if Senator Bartlett continues to take this point of view I might start to send the letters to him so that he can see that there are a lot of people who are very concerned about this. I do not believe the bill deserves a reading in this place, certainly not in the form in which it is at the moment. If it does come up for reading I will certainly be voting against it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The report that Senator O'Chee talks about is a very important report. It arises following a bill that was brought into the chamber by one of Senator Bartlett's predecessors, Senator Spindler, a man of some eminence—
—A good Democrat.

—A good Democrat, and someone who spoke very much in favour of human rights, I might say. As I understand it, Senator O'Chee—who is a considerable sportsman himself and a good coach too—has raised this issue on several occasions. I was associated with the majority report, but I have spoken to people connected with this report, the leaders who actually directed the writing of it, and their understanding is that what Senator O'Chee complains about is not contained in the report. I think Senator O'Chee has raised some mighty issues here, but they arise from a concept of the report which others would dispute. I think he turned his mind fairly to this and said that if Senator Bolkus were here he might take a different view. I suggest that this report be kept on the list, and later I will move that.

speech.para: May I say, having a daughter who is a considerable sportswoman, in the water and as a runner and elsewhere, that I certainly think it would be unfair that she should be put up against people who had attributes that were in addition to those that a female should have. When I think of our great woman athlete, the golden girl Betty Cuthbert, who you would not remember seeing run, Senator Evans, because she ran before your time—

talk.start.para: —I thought she ran before your time too, Barney.

—I was there in 1956 and saw her win the 100 metres race. Shirley Strickland and Dawn Fraser were other great Australian women athletes over the years. The most tragic circumstances were those that affected Raelene Boyle, who I think would have had two gold medals for Australia but for drugs that people from East Germany used. Senator O'Chee is correct in saying that sporting contests should be fair, but what is in dispute is the contents of the report. In those circumstances, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

speech.para: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: —This report is entitled Importation of cooked chicken meat into Australia . In the recent round of estimates there was certain additional material which I think needs to be put on the record in relation to this matter. On 22 January last year the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy announced a final round of tests designed to confirm the cooking parameters required to enable the safe importation of cooked chicken meat. The minister was in fact forced into undertaking further research by the findings of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs, this committee, on the risk assessment undertaken by AQIS. The Bureau of Resource Sciences was commissioned by AQIS to supervise the trials and selected the Central Veterinary Laboratory in Weybridge, England. This facility has a very high international reputation with the scientific community and has acknowledged expertise in both Newcastle disease and infectious bursal disease. I understand that the Waybridge facility has access to virulent strains of both these diseases and has high security facilities to enable proper trials to be carried out. I also understand that the protocols for these trials were agreed by the Bureau of Resource Sciences, AQIS, the Weybridge scientists and the Australian industry. So we had arguably the best scientists in the world and we had a process agreed by the BRS and AQIS itself, and cleared by the Australian industry.

speech.para: The work found that the protocols recommended by AQIS were inadequate for infectious bursal disease. As a result, AQIS commissioned a special scientific working group to evaluate the Weybridge results. The terms of reference stated in part that the group should `advise as to why the results differ from previous heat inactivation trial results on IBDV.'

This was no ordinary group of scientists; they were the best available. The group was chaired by Dr Gardiner Murray from AQIS and included Dr Bill Geering from the Bureau of Resource Science, Dr Trevor Bagust from the University of Melbourne, Dr Bob Steele from the CSIRO, Jeff Fairbrother and Margaret McKenzie from the industry, and Dr Andrew Turner who is Victoria's chief vet. I understand the group reported to AQIS in early January and advised that the Weybridge tests were soundly based and accurate. The group said the Weybridge results differed from the earlier AQIS work because of the virus strains used and the medium in which the virus was tested; that is, the testing carried out by Weybridge generated different and more appropriate data because it was more relevant to the nature of the product being assessed.

It appears that, despite this process being accepted by AQIS and despite the fact that this laboratory has an international reputation for its expertise in Newcastle disease and infectious bursal disease, AQIS is now questioning the results of the trials. This approach by AQIS does not augur well for the post-Nairn appropriate risk assessment process; that is, the use of independent panels to undertake controversial assessments.

I repeat that this work was carried out by arguably the best laboratory in the world in this field. Its results were reviewed by a panel selected and appointed by AQIS, but AQIS apparently is still not prepared to accept these findings. The scientific working group also found that the time temperature regime, I assume constructed by AQIS based on the Weybridge data, is flawed.

I was advised in estimates by the executive director of AQIS, Mr Paul Hickey, that issues about the construction of the time and temperature parameters were raised by this group. Mr Hickey confirmed that, subject to further input from the Weybridge scientists, the time temperature regime released in November by Minister Anderson was inadequate. The times, it appears, were too short and the cooking temperatures may well be too low. This outcome does little to improve the confidence in the quarantine import risk assessment process.

This is an outcome that must be of considerable concern not only to the chicken industry but also to those other industries that currently face exposure to imported product if the markets are relaxed or access to our markets is relaxed by determinations by AQIS. They include the salmon industry; the pork industry, which has been the subject of some recent relaxation of controls on the importation of pork products; and the apple and pear industry, on which I note there have been articles in the newspaper about the renewal of the consideration of applications by New Zealand to introduce those products into Australia. I think this is a matter of great concern and this is a matter that will be watched closely by the opposition.

talk.start.para: —I have just learnt the facts that were discovered at estimates—that AQIS made a mistake. The tests were not as we thought at the time and, as has obviously now been proven, assumptions were not able to be made based on the original tests and carried through. With what AQIS and the minister responsible have nearly done there is still the potential, unless it is sorted out, to undermine and erode this very important industry to Australia and particularly to New South Wales.

speech.para: It is essential to remember that the chicken industry is the largest employer in the Hunter Valley. This government has done very little for the Hunter Valley. We have seen the retrenchment of steelworkers and we have seen the impact of their industrial relations upon the mines. But now we see that they are continuing to not care about the Hunter Valley and they are continuing to put at risk the largest employer in that area. You move up the Hunter Valley and up the New England Highway to the Speaker's electorate of New England and there you have another significant chicken industry. That area is a major employer also. The central coast of New South Wales, the north of the Illawarra and the MIA are other significant chicken industry areas in this state. They are significant employers. We know that Bartters in Griffith has just announced plans to employ an extra 1,000 people.

This is a government that has done nothing for regional development—nothing at all. They gutted the regional development part of their department. They got rid of it. They got it from 230-odd employees down to about six. Now they are not prepared to bite the bullet and say, `We were wrong about what we were going to do. We should not be allowing imports of cooked or other chicken meat into this country because the danger of disease is too great.'

This government just does not seem to be able to comprehend that AQIS has not been able to get it right. They do not seem to be able to comprehend that a decision needs to be made to give certainty and assurance to this very important industry, and that it needs to be able to continue. The investments need to be able to continue. People like the Bartters at Griffith need to be certain that the current government is not going to allow the importation into this country of diseases that will not only decimate the chicken industry but will also decimate the bird population of this country.

I think it ill behoves the government to sit here and continue to do nothing. A number of us have been making pleas for some considerable time. We have sat on committees, moved around the state and taken evidence and, if the government does nothing, it will be on their heads that they have chosen to ignore the work of the committee, which has been a bipartisan committee and the findings have been bipartisan. We are now having expert evidence being brought to the estimates committee to indicate that the concerns of the industry which were brought to our attention are correct. I think that it is disgusting. It needs to be remedied and the government has it within its power to do so, instead of going around saying, `Oh, we need new research. We need new evidence.' The evidence is actually there. It actually got Dr Alexander to do specialist work on the specific issues and the specific diseases that they were trying to extrapolate from his original research that would apply to the other organisms.

The fact that Dr Alexander's work does not prove what AQIS thought was right is significant. It proves there are the dangers, and we cannot afford to see further attacks on rural Australia, particularly rural New South Wales in this particular situation. As I have said, this is a major employer of people in areas of this state. When we are talking about the introduction of any of these diseases, we are talking about the loss of thousands and thousands of jobs, we are talking about the possible safety of people who eat the product, and we are talking about the decimation of the avian population in this country.

It really concerns me that a number of the green groups have not actually looked at this particular issue and do not seem to be cognisant of the danger to the avian species in this country, to the biodiversity of this country, and to the uniqueness of our avian population. We have a number of birds in this country that are only found here, and it would be absolutely criminal, in an environmental context, to run the risk of destroying that very beautiful and very special unique population that we have. I certainly urge the green groups to start to take an interest in this. This is the sort of devastation of our native fauna that, once it happens, it is too late—it is gone, we will have lost it. We will not have just lost one or two species, we could lose whole genera.

It is a very sad situation. I think it behoves the government to very speedily make a decision, for a number of very valid and very important reasons that I have outlined here. It is an important issue. There is a major industry in this country that is put under threat. The longer this government goes on not taking into consideration those points, the greater at risk this industry will be. The government must do something quickly and make the announcements so that the industry has certainty and surety and people are sure that their jobs will remain. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

debateinfo.title: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO VENEZUELA AND THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

talk.start.para: —by leave—The particular aspect of the delegation's visit to the United States that I would like to focus on tonight concerns a visit to the city of New York and, in particular, briefings that were given by the police commissioner in New York. The city of New York—the Big Apple as we know it—conjures up all sorts of visions in people's minds. We have seen it on film and we have seen it on television. There is no doubt it evokes quite powerful images for many Australians and, in fact, for many people all over the world.

speech.para: I think one of the aspects of the city's urban mythology focuses on Central Park. It is known as the lungs of the city and it is probably the focus of the city for many millions of people, both residents and visitors. When I went to New York in 1992, I was warned about Central Park: it was off limits if you went there alone; you should not take a handbag there; you should not visit late in the afternoon; and you certainly should not go near the park after dark—although, of course, it is actually closed to the public after dark. It was certainly seen as an area of particularly high crime and a good deal of violent crime. These days millions of people are using that park for family activities and doing so in quite amazing safety, just a couple of years after it was one of the most dangerous parts of the city.

This has happened because the police in New York, under the guidance of the Police Commissioner Howard Safir, have taken on the responsibility of making the city and, in particular, the park, safe for families. The police go into the park on foot, on horses, on scooters and on bicycles. They go in uniform and they go in plain clothes. They are everywhere in that park, and that park is now known as an area which is policed to the extent that it is safer now than it was 30 years ago.

Howard Safir briefed the delegation about the ways in which he has taken on this challenge together with the mayor of New York and how he has made New York one of the safest large cities in the world and certainly in the United States. They have done quite an astonishing job. It is now a pleasure to walk the streets and the parklands of New York. You see small children playing without apparent close supervision, and the streets are noticeably free of panhandlers and beggars, which are things you see in some of the other larger cities in the United States. There has been a 60 per cent decrease in murders in New York and 165 fewer murders just during the last year alone. In fact, it is back to the levels of the late sixties.

Howard Safir told us about the strategy that he has implemented to bring about this remarkable change. I would like to share it with the Senate tonight. It is a concept known as the broken window strategy. It is based on the idea that taking no action on minor crimes such as graffiti, broken windows, panhandling, bag snatching, and so on, gives a very clear message that the community at large is prepared to tolerate this sort of crime, that it really does not matter all that much. People would think, `Oh well, there is already one broken window, another one will not make much difference at all,' and, `I have seen some graffiti on that building, but it is not too bad, so I will not worry about it.'

The broken window strategy targets police efforts with the small core of criminals, both hard criminals and petty criminals, who are responsible for the major crime on the streets of New York. This quite fresh approach of what I would call zero tolerance of crime has deterred quite an amazing amount of crime from the streets and parklands of that city. It targets crime before it gets out of hand, before it gets to be big crime and before it gets to be serious, violent crime.

These efforts to fight the city's crime rate have been a remarkable success. If only we could say the same for Australia. Our cities are a visual disgrace. Graffiti appears on some of our more historic and beautiful buildings. Then there is the bag snatching, the assaults on the elderly, the shoplifting and the house break-ins, and so on. Most of all, there are the assaults on, and even murders of, the very men and women whom we employ in this country to enforce our laws—our police officers.

Our cities have become a terrifying prospect for people who are alone at night on the footpaths, in the car parks and in the quite beautiful park lands, where as soon as it begins to get dark you cannot go to them. After dark, our cities become dangerous ghost towns. They are run by the lawless, the gangs, the dealers, the pimps and the standover bullies.

Criminologists have identified the cost of this upsurge in crime. Motor vehicle theft is now costing the Australian community over $1 billion a year. There were 351 murders in Australia in 1995, and 334,000 Australians were victims of assault or threats of violence. Many of them were elderly and many of them were in their own homes at the time. In one year alone 300,000 burglaries had cost us almost $1 billion. What a tragic set of statistics and what a tragedy for Australia.

Howard Safir, the New York police commissioner, is an impressive man. He is a police commissioner who has accepted and implemented the challenge of returning the city of New York to its people and to the tourists who go there. There is no doubt our police do the very best they are able, but resources and the sheer weight of the bully boys has even daunted them. We saw the terrible evidence of that in Sydney just this past week.

Our community, the same as the community of New York, wants safer streets, cleaner cities and less dangerous parklands. So do the people of New York, and Howard Safir has delivered it. He has shared his broken window strategy with us, and I would commend that everybody read the document and think about the suggestions that he has made in it.

talk.start.para: —Order! I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight in the adjournment debate to discuss a matter which goes to the heart of this government's inability to recognise the consequences of its decisions on regional Australia. Over the next few minutes, I wish to discuss a matter which, when you look at the issues in detail, raises a number of questions about the commitment of this government to our regions. In doing so, I will highlight the hypocrisy of the government, who for years have claimed the small business constituency as their own and who went to the last election promising to give small business a bigger slice of the government procurement cake through changes in purchasing policy and practice.

speech.para: The matter I wish to raise tonight is the decision of the Australian Taxation Office to terminate a contract with a small Tasmanian security firm in favour of a national contract with an international security services provider. Senator Newman should be well aware of this case because, as I understand from the constituents concerned, the firm has forwarded to her all the relevant documents. However, we have not heard anything from Senator Newman, so I intend to take up the matter directly with the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey) myself. It is his responsibility to ensure that the government's promise to small business on purchasing policy is delivered.

I would like to begin by telling the Senate a little bit about the security firm concerned, which is Pelham Security. Pelham Security are a Tasmanian owned and operated company. The directors, Kevin and Gail Pelham, advised me they employ directly and indirectly 75 Tasmanians. It has provided 75 jobs in the state with the nation's highest unemployment rate. I am also advised that all profits from this business are spent in Tasmania.

Pelham Security have been providing security services to the Australian Taxation Office at their Collins Street offices since 1995. The original contract was for two years, and it was renewed last October for a further 12 months. This all may seem pretty straightforward to most senators, except for the fact that the government has decided to terminate this contract with effect from 31 March—a decision which is all the more outrageous, given that Pelham Security have neither breached, nor been accused of breaching, their contract at any time. Whilst the contract provides for early termination, what is particularly concerning for me is that, for Pelham Security to seek just compensation, in accordance with section 9.1 of their contract, expensive and resource intensive legal action will now be required.

This now takes me to the substance of my concerns: the failure of the government to understand the connection or nexus between decisions such as these and their inevitable and exponential impact on employment in regional Australia. The issue of costs associated with seeking compensation is an important one for small business. Pelham Security have advised me that, on the basis of this contract, business decisions were taken to increase investment in capital equipment—investment that is critically important to regional Australia; investment that, in turn, delivers the jobs growth that regions require to continue to be viable in social and economic terms.

The decision to make significant investments is a difficult one for most businesses, but it is particularly difficult for small businesses. A situation where a small business can have its contract cancelled—the carpet pulled out from under them—at any time does not augur well for future investment and employment growth. It is important to remember that, when we look at employment growth, the small to medium business sector is the key contributor.

So, in a nutshell, what we have here is a government which is gushing in its rhetoric with respect to small business, employment growth and regional development. But it is a government that fails to understand the important role that its expenditure plays in this cycle of development.

In conclusion, I would like to return to the plight of Pelham Security. It is critical that the government resolve this matter quickly and with minimal inconvenience to Pelham Security and its staff. Quite apart from the fact that this problem should never have occurred in the first place, it is important that the government learn from this case study in small business insensitivity.

As I mentioned earlier, the contract concerned allows for early termination, but it does so in conjunction with clause 9.2, which allows for `fair and reasonable compensation'. I urge the government to abide by this clause, and to do so swiftly. I also urge the government to move beyond rhetoric and deliver on its commitment to give small business a fair go—and to particularly sort the situation out with regard to Pelham Security. If it fails to do so, it will—as far as Mr Pelham, his security firm and myself are concerned— continue to demonstrate its complete contempt for regional Australia.

talk.start.para: —This evening I rise to bring to the attention of the Senate some of what I believe is the very good news in the Australian film industry and arts community, in particular. I think even we allegedly out of touch parliamentarians manage to recognise that Australia has a thriving film industry.

speech.para: In the last two years we have had several top Australian films competing at the Cannes film festival. In 1996 we were represented by the Quiet Room, Love Serenade, and No Way to Forget; and two short films, My Film is a Dog, and Noir. Again in May of last year, The Well and the short film Final Cut were featured at Cannes, while many films were launched there, including Blackrock, Doing Time for Patsy Cline, Kiss or Kill and Thank God He Met Lizzie. The next few weeks will see the launch of the second film of Children of the Revolution director and university contemporary of mine, Peter Duncan—A Little Bit of Soul.

There are many Australian films in the international market which reflect the exciting range of skill and talent in our film industry. Many of our film makers and actors have now established outstanding international reputations, and a growing number of Australian productions are earning valuable export income for this country in a hugely competitive industry. I think it is worth noting that women, in particular, in the Australian film industry have been very successful in leading the way in recent years. At the highly commercial end of proceedings, Australia has seen the success of Mel Gibson at the 1996 Academy Awards with Braveheart winning the best film and best director; and also, of course, the highly popular Babe—which was filmed in my family's local area, the Southern Highlands—being awarded an Oscar for best visual effects.

It is a sign of the growing successes of our film industry that last year Australian films and film makers received more Academy Award nominations than ever before in the history of our participation in the industry. The crowning glory for many in 1997 was, no doubt, Geoffrey Rush's achievements in Shine, emerging from both the Academy Awards and the Golden Globe awards with the Best Actor award. I note that Geoffrey Rush is also a star of A Little Bit of Soul. John Seale was also awarded an Oscar for cinematography in The English Patient.

In December last year, the Australian film Road to Nhill won the Best Film category at the Sebrika Film Festival in Greece, following on from our own AFI award night where Kiss or Kill scooped the pool. Australia had four `road' movies which particularly featured in last year's AFI awards—and they could have been stories from any corner of the globe. But critics recognise that why they stand out is because of a boldness of vision, at times an almost feral quality, and a confidence in telling the stories that rejects gimmicks and studio compromises. This underscores the reality that our film industry is, by its nature, very independent. Our contemporary films consistently display richness and diversity, great self-confidence, and industry depth.

The knowledge that our film makers can take a risk, can be true to their original vision, means that passions are not left in the bottom drawer for want of money. Coming from Sydney as I do, aircraft noise is often a major issue on our front pages—but the film The Castle, financed largely by the Frontline team, was brought to international prominence on front pages in that it was made in only six weeks, for $700,000, and grossed $10.3 million at the box office. It also picked up a 1997 AFI award for best original screenplay.

Industry investors such as producers, distributors, exhibitors and broadcasters are increasingly sharing the faith, and I think the passion, of the industry. According to the Australian Film Commission, investment by these players rose significantly as a proportion of budgets in 1996-97. This is an important sign that we have an industry that can attract increased revenue from domestic and export sales. One must also recognise the role of the Film Finance Corporation in facilitating increasing levels of industry investment.

Our film and television industry is a powerhouse. Indeed, in the last 12 months it has gone from strength to strength, and there is no doubt that the Australian film and television industry currently enjoys great international recognition. Australians are being sought for their skills in every field of film making—from editing to cinematography to the brave new world of multimedia.

While international recognition is important, and in fact crucial, we must never lose sight of the importance of the industry to Australia, especially to our future on both cultural and economic fronts. We all know how much pride we take in seeing our nation celebrated at film festivals around the globe. We like to read of high praise for our actors, like LA Confidential stars Russell Crowe and Guy Pearce in Hollywood; and see script writers like Laura Jones in so much demand overseas. We do have something unique to offer. The world knows it and wants it.

Last year a Roy Morgan poll found that 88 per cent of Australians believe the Australian film industry is important in raising both the general image of Australia and awareness of our country overseas. More importantly, the poll also found that 75 per cent of Australians believe that films produced by our film industry are equal to, if not better than, those made overseas. So faith in the industry and the arts world is solid at home.

But it is not an overnight success; it comes from years and years of creative toil. Australia, many would say, is approaching its finest hour in terms of international profile at least. Our foray into the next millennium will be a very public one, as the world's eyes focus on Sydney during the 2000 Olympics and later our centenary of federation celebrations. It is during times of national reflection such as the centenary of federation that we will appreciate more than ever the role film plays in capturing key moments in a nation's life.

I well remember the film showed earlier this year at the beginning of the women's constitutional convention—a film about federation, which at the time was intended to depict the process of federation itself but was shown at the women's constitutional convention to show the involvement of women in the process. It was a very telling and a very interesting reflection on that period.

Our ability to critically analyse our history is enhanced by the preservation of the work of previous generations of film and television creators. Clearly, the National Film and Sound Archive and Film Australia are key players as we celebrate the turn of the century and, in particular, the documentary will prove to be an ideal vehicle for telling our stories. But the reality is that the social documentary is the least commercially viable but one of the most culturally relevant film genres. Ongoing market failure and occasionally lack of government support could have meant that programs such as Rats in the Ranks and The Year of the Dogs might not have been made. For either football or political followers, we would have been the poorer.

The government wants as many Australians as possible to enjoy the insights, reflections and often unique perspectives that the documentary provides. To this end, the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) announced in November last year, as part of the government's response to the Gonski report, that we will continue Film Australia's national interest program at current levels of $6.4 million per annum from 1999-00 to 2002-03.

Film Australia is the jewel in the documentary crown, through not only the management of the national interest program but the marketing and the distribution it undertakes on behalf of other producers; its archives, described often as Australia's photo album of more than 80 years of film making; and its Lindfield site.

I am also actively pursuing the question of continued funding of SBSI, the production arm of SBS. SBSI is in the rare position of being a government funded production arm looking for a specific network and audience. Because it is audience and topic specific, as well as dedicated to broadening the base of storytelling on our screens, its programs often find a much wider audience.

Our industry infrastructure, while still being finetuned, is working well enough to attract international production to our shores. The government recognises the capacity of that production undertaken in Australia to assist local industry through skills development and employment, particularly of technical crews.

We are working towards achieving a mature, dynamic and sustainable film industry. To this end, we initiated the Gonski inquiry, which investigated the operations of the film industry in Australia. The report called for new measures to increase private investment while retaining direct funding as a principal mechanism of government assistance, refinement of current Commonwealth film agencies' functions and a changed role for Film Australia.

The report was responded to last November. The details of that response are well known, but I do want to stress its main points, including the retention of Film Australia as Commonwealth owned—a vertically integrated company—and retention of their Lindfield facilities; retention of Film Australia's archives; extension of their national interest program until 2003; and the introduction of a new pilot scheme—the film licensed investment scheme—providing a 100 tax concession to investors in companies which are licensed to invest in a slate of film and television productions. This will raise concessional capital of up to $20 million a year for two years from 1998-99.

The Gonski model offers an innovative approach to balancing the needs of government for efficiency and accountability with the needs of investors for incentives to invest in Australian film and television. Any opportunities to increase the efficiency of support to industry should be pursued. The FLIC model offers a number of advantages in this regard, in particular in terms of transparency, accountability and certainty of funding.

Our response to the report was well received as a whole. This is as a reflection of the government's approach to the arts community and as we see the role of government not to dictate or impose cultural norms but to create an environment which fosters—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Tonight I rise to say a few words about the passing of two great figures of the trade union movement. The first person whom I wish to refer to is Edgar Williams, who passed away in December last year. Edgar was a renowned figure in the Australian trade union movement, particularly the Australian Workers Union, and the Australian Labor Party.

speech.para: My colleague Senator John Hogg made a most moving and eloquent speech yesterday in which he recorded the achievements of Edgar. I compliment John on his remarks. John, like me, had the great pleasure of knowing Edgar for many years. I certainly endorse Senator Hogg's remarks yesterday, but I just want to add a few of my own.

I first met Edgar Williams in 1976, when I commenced employment with the Australian Workers Union as a junior industrial officer. I was pretty green but I learned quickly, as you have to in the world of trade unions and industrial relations. You often find that there are more jobs to be done and causes to fight than you have time for.

Edgar Williams was an inspiration to me, as he was indeed to all the officials of the Australian Workers Union for well over 40 years. When I met him, he was the federal president of the AWU and the AWU's representative on the ACTU executive. I attended annual conventions each year after that at which Edgar presided as the federal president of the union, up until his retirement in 1982.

One of Edgar's great strengths was his ability as chairman of the AWU's conventions. As I am sure honourable senators would be aware—if they have not heard it or read about it, they could certainly imagine—conventions of the AWU, given the long history of that union, were often very interesting and very fiery occasions. But Edgar had this incredible ability to earn the respect and the admiration of all of the delegates at those conventions, whether they supported him or opposed him. This was so much so that I think Clyde Cameron carried on for many years a struggle in the union against Edgar. Even when Clyde entered this parliament, he carried it on. He, nevertheless, I am sure, would pay tribute to Edgar's strength of character, strength of purpose, and dedication to working men and women.

Edgar was honoured with life membership of the AWU, with life membership of the Australian Labor Party and as one of the great figures of the Australian trade union movement. I, as I said, learnt much from Edgar and I certainly pay tribute to his lifelong dedication to his union, the AWU, and to its members.

I also want to record the passing of and make some comments about another great trade union official who was very much like Edgar, and that was Maurie Rudd. Maurie Rudd was an official of the Federated Ironworkers Association, which in 1993 amalgamated with the AWU. When Maurie passed away on 7 February this year, he also was an official of the AWU. I think it is probably best if I quote from an article that appeared in the Australian written by a lifelong friend of Maurie Rudd's, because it sets out far better than I can Maurie's achievements. It states:
Maurie Rudd was born in Goulburn, NSW, in 1942, the son of a working-class rural family with strong labour-movement links.
He left school at an early age and was largely self-taught, being an avid reader. He held many jobs, mainly unskilled; he was working in a shearing shed when he first became a member of the AWU.
The similarities with Edgar are very relevant there. It goes on to say:

He became a beltman's assistant in the sinter plant at BHP Newcastle steelworks in July 1970. It was a hard and dirty job. He said he took it because it involved so much overtime and he needed the money for his family. In his time there he saw four men killed at work. The need for safety on the job and improved working conditions and wages were the motivating factors in his becoming a steelworkers' delegate. In June 1985, he became an acting organiser of the Federated Ironworkers Association. Later that year he became a national organiser, was elected as a branch organiser and then became acting assistant secretary.
He was elected branch secretary in 1989, a position he held until his death.

Like Edgar, Maurie had the opportunities to become a member of parliament and accept higher offices. But Maurie, like Edgar, spurned those opportunities and spent his entire life working in the trade union movement for his fellow working men. He also was active in the Australian Labor Party and played a notable role in that regard, particularly in the Newcastle region.

The sad part about Maurie Rudd, but nevertheless it is something that demonstrates his strength of character, relates to the fact that, when BHP announced last year that it would close the Newcastle steelworks, Maurie was once again called to action. He took up the challenge and led the campaign by the workers at BHP in Newcastle and the citizens of Newcastle to face that shock announcement by BHP. It came very much like an earthquake to Newcastle. He led delegations down here to Canberra to lobby the Prime Minister and other politicians to do something on behalf of Newcastle so that we would not see that great industrial city die.

But, whilst he was doing that, whilst he was spending 24 hours a day seeking to represent his members and the people of Newcastle, he was dying of lung cancer and was receiving chemotherapy treatment. He carried on throughout that campaign, notwithstanding the great illness that he was suffering. I know that the workers of Newcastle and the members of his union are proud of his dedication and his work on their behalf in that dispute.

Both Edgar Williams and Maurie Rudd were big men in size. They were big in heart and they made big achievements throughout their working lives. They were big Australians. I think it is appropriate that we record in this parliament their achievements on behalf of their fellow working men and women.

Whilst I note that quite often members of the coalition take great delight in attacking the trade union movement and trade union leaders, I would ask, in closing, that maybe they pause a while and read and examine the stories of people like Edgar Williams and Maurie Rudd—people who started their lives in poverty or in hard times; who saw that there was a need to represent workers and did so; and who also strongly believed in democratic trade unionism, something which ultimately is a protection for all citizens whether they be trade union officials or not. As I have said before, when tyranny raises its head, it is very often the trade union movement, along with the churches, that are first attacked and silenced. People like Edgar Williams and Maurie Rudd were great Australians who achieved much for their fellow Australians. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Yesterday, the Senate passed an historic censure of a shadow minister—the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Bolkus. The censure was based on Senator Bolkus knowingly and deliberately revealing to members of the media the contents of a confidential Federal Court document, putting at risk the taxpayer-funded pursuit of Mr Skase's assets. This action is in breach of any code of acceptable conduct. The shadow Attorney-General—the would-be first law officer of this country—deliberately and knowingly revealed sensitive information from a confidential court document.

speech.para: In the unlikely event that Labor wins the next election, we now know the standards Mr Beazley will set for his ministry. If Senator Bolkus were to become Attorney-General, he would deal with confidential and sensitive matters every day. Indeed, he would have carriage of the Skase matter as Attorney-General. He would thereby become privy to the actions being taken against Mr Skase. And what would he do? If he saw a short-sighted political benefit in revealing certain information, Senator Bolkus, by his actions, has revealed he would have no compunction about revealing it to the media. And Mr Beazley, by allowing Senator Bolkus to remain in the Attorney-General portfolio, is also saying that he would condone such behaviour.

This lack of commitment to any standards by Mr Beazley has exposed Mr Beazley's weakness as leader which, in itself, is another issue of standards aside from the scurrilous activities of the rusty pipe opposite. It is in that light that Labor's attack on the Minister for Resources and Energy has been so duplicitous. It is also in that light that I express my regret that the media has seen fit to publicise and peddle the Labor-orchestrated campaign against the minister for resources and largely remain silent in relation to the overwhelming vote of censure against a shadow minister for his unacceptable conduct, his failure to resign and his failure to be sacked.

These are matters of genuine public interest. The public do have a right to know and the media has failed in its duty. In saying that the media failed, I trust this silence was not to protect a person who has gained an unenviable record around this place for giving unauthorised information to the media. As one member of the media is reputed to have said, `We won't bite the hand that feeds us.' That type of cynicism is regrettable and, I trust, is not widespread, let alone the reason for this strange silence.

I ask my friends in the media to look through their records and then their consciences, and see how much coverage they gave to the Senate's vote of condemnation—not censure—of a Liberal opposition backbencher three years ago for his inadvertent—and I stress inadvertent—disclosure of a tax file number—something he did, might I add, by leave granted to him by a Labor senator. Or they might search their records and then their consciences as to their actions when a Liberal frontbencher in opposition unwittingly divulged confidential information in the Hindmarsh Island matter.

Yesterday's vote was not only historic in itself; it was an overwhelming vote of censure for the unparalleled and unprincipled release of confidential court documents by the alternate Attorney-General. This breach of standards, on any objective analysis, was worthy of at least equal to, if not greater than, time and space in the media as the scurrilous accusations being made against the minister for resources. I do not seek special treatment for my party, just equal treatment.

talk.start.para: —I want to spend a few moments and incorporate into Hansard an anomaly, as I see it, within the diesel fuel rebate scheme. There was at first a tax on petrol in 1929 that had nothing to do with the Depression but certainly did not assist it. The first diesel fuel tax was imposed in 1957, and it was imposed as a measure against road-using vehicles only. It was never intended for that to be used for any vehicles or engines or other mode of consumption of diesel off road. It was always envisaged that mining, agriculture, forestry and the fishing industries would be exempted. Without that exemption, some businesses would surely close and would close in the immediate and medium term.

speech.para: The survivors would endure some hardship—and there is no argument against that. Australia would experience a significant short-term drop in income, plus a diminution of expenditure outlays. Australian shares and stocks would certainly drop. Future exploration, on which this country so vitally depends for its standard of living, would be inhibited, and low-grade mining ventures would also close or at least be curtailed. Certainly, we would lose overseas markets and an imposition of excise would, by all reasonable economic measures, be revenue neutral in those cases.

Western Australia is the biggest per capita user or consumer of diesel and heavy fuel in the nation. It is, paradoxically, the biggest producer now of petroleum and petroleum and gas products. National export income totals about 30 per cent from Western Australia. So that ties the economy of Australia in very real terms to the health of Western Australia.

Western Australia is by far the biggest mining state in the nation. It happens to have within its boundaries the biggest diamond mine in the world, mining some 38 million carats in the last complete fiscal year. It mines 80 per cent of Australia's gold. It has the biggest iron ore mines in the world. It is the biggest producer and exporter of alumina powder in the world. It produces more heavy mineral sands, particularly ilmenite, from which it produces synthetic rutile, in the world.

If we recognise that, we must surely recognise that other aspects of mining in Western Australia are very important to the mining industry. I speak specifically of the mining of limestone in Western Australia. Limestone throughout Australia is a fundamental part of mining and a fundamental part of the steel and building industry. Some of the producers of limestone in Australia are Swan Portland Cement Ltd, Adelaide Brighton Cement Ltd, Blue Circle Southern Cement Ltd, Lime Industries Pty Ltd, David Mitchell (NSW) Pty Ltd, Cockburn Cement Ltd, Pacific Lime, Northern Cement Ltd, BHP Steel, Queensland Cement, Amalg Resources of Kalgoorlie and Westlime (WA) Ltd.

Limestone, regrettably, initially did not attract the diesel fuel rebate. An appeal was made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and it found, not illogically, that the mining of limestone was, in fact, mining, and they reinstated the diesel fuel rebate to the limestone miners. However, with bureaucracy gone mad, I believe, in this instance, the Australian Customs Service has now appealed that decision and the limestone producers in Australia are now awaiting the outcome of that decision. Justice, it would seem, is not quick and is certainly not cheap. I do not want to take the issue too far but I do appreciate the time and the forum of this chamber to bring it to the attention of members here—those members who are diehard and left here. I appreciate the three who are in the chamber tonight.

In the few minutes left, I wish to give an example of two areas that I believe are wrong. The mining of marble in Australia is considered to be mining, yet marble is predominantly, if not exclusively, calcium carbonate. Limestone is calcium carbonate, yet the Australian Customs Service, which I think is an anomaly—the last word is anyway—has said that it is not; it is an extractive industry. Extractive industries in the United Kingdom, for instance, are classified as miners or miners are classified in the United Kingdom exclusively as extractive industries. Why there should be a distinction drawn between the mining of marble and the mining of its cousin, its very close relation, limestone, I do not know, but I would be very interested to find out.

Dampier Salt is also in Western Australia. At the risk of bragging once again, it is the biggest solar operation in the southern hemisphere. Although it harvests the salt, Dampier Salt is subject to the diesel fuel rebate scheme. It is not a tax that they should pay. It was never imposed and never meant to be a tax and it should not be seen as such. But Dampier Salt is allowed to windrow its sodium chloride. It is allowed to pick up the sodium chloride in mechanical harvesters, load it on to trucks and take it to a stockpile where it dries out, because it is quite wet. That part of the operation is subject to the rebate. But once the stockpile is taken from the same mining lease to the wharf for export, that is not subject to the diesel fuel rebate.

These are some areas in our mining industry on which this country depends for its standard of living, for its wealth, for its value added and for its employment. We should look to enhance that, not to inhibit it. Any tax on the mining industry is a tax on exports. That is something that I find convoluted and not in the best interests of Australia.

Thirty per cent of diesel is used on roads but 70 per cent is used off roads in the mining industry, the farming industry and the fishing industry, et cetera. We should make this uniform within the mining industry. I believe it is an anomaly to attempt to exclude the limestone extractors. I appreciate having the time to draw this to the Senate's attention. I trust that those people who are responsible for the Australian Customs Service will let a little logic apply and consider the mining of limestone mining.

talk.start.para: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I just ask for a point of clarification. Senator Lightfoot asked for permission to incorporate. Is that from the document he has just quoted from?

—Senator Lightfoot said, `I wish to incorporate.' I think he meant that he wished to put it on the record. He used `incorporate' in a way that means something special to us in the Senate. I do not think he wanted to incorporate a document.
