debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 26 November 1997:

question.para: With reference to the $4.5 million set aside by the department for research into electromagnetic radiation and public health:

(1) By what process does the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) select members to the committee of experts involved in the dissemination of funds to prospective researchers in this area.
(2) What are the selection criteria for admission onto the committee.
(3) Who is currently on the committee.
(4) How often and when does the committee meet.

(5) Does the NHMRC have any policy concerning membership on selection committees that deal with dissemination of funds for research into industry issues of people who are concurrently employed by the same industry.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: The $4.5 million RF EME program comprises an Australian research program, managed by the NHMRC, participation in the World Health Organisations' EMF Project and a public information program.
The Office of NHMRC, within the Department of Health and Family Services has advised that:

(1) The NHMRC EME Expert Committee is a sub-Committee of the Strategic Research Development Committee (SRDC), which is a Principal Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council. The Expert Committee was established by the SRDC to oversee all aspects of the research process. The SRDC, at its meeting in July 1997, selected two SRDC members to co-Chair the EME Expert Committee.

The first step in the nomination process for the Expert Committee was to determine health and professional fields relevant to the issues identified in the document developed by the Committee on Electromagnetic Energy Public Health Issues titled "Strategy for an Australian research program into possible health issues associated with exposure to communications radiofrequencies". These fields included Epidemiology, Cancer Biology, Physical Dosimetry and Nuclear Medicine.
The Committee co-Chairs, with Secretariat assistance, initially investigated membership, with final membership endorsed by the SRDC at its September 1997 meeting.

(2) Members of the NHMRC EME Expert Committee were appointed on the basis of their widely recognised expertise in areas of science relevant to the responsibilities of the NHMRC in managing the EME research program.

(3) The Committee currently consists of: Dr Donald Cameron (Co-Chair); Prof Judith Black (Co-Chair); Prof Bruce Armstrong; Prof Tony Basten; Prof Annette Dobson; Dr Alan Harris; Dr Ken Joyner; Dr Frederick Khafagi; Dr Keith Lokan; Prof Colin Thompson.
(4) The Committee meets on an ad hoc basis, as required. Meetings to date have been held in October and December 1997, with a further meeting anticipated around May/June 1998.

(5) The NHMRC has well established conflict of interest guidelines for a range of situations. These include a requirement for "Disclosure of interests" section 29 (1-5) of the NHMRC Act 1992. In addition, each Committee develops its own, more specific guidelines designed to optimise the range and level of expert advice while removing influences from conflicts of interest in committee members. For example, these principles may include that—no scientific collaborator or departmental colleague of an applicant is called upon to assess a grant application.

The SRDC has developed conflict of interest guidelines for the NHMRC EME Expert Committee. The guidelines apply to all members of the NHRMC EME Expert Committee. All members have declared their actual or potential conflicts of interest. This is an ongoing requirement for the term of the membership. An excerpt of the EME procedures regarding conflict of interest follows:

- In the case of direct pecuniary interest, members may not take part in any decision to which the potential conflict of direct pecuniary interest applies, and must physically absent themselves from all or any part of a formal meeting or other discussion at which the matter in question is being discussed.

- Where there is a potential indirect pecuniary or non-pecuniary interest, the Chair of the Expert Committee, in consultation with the other uninvolved members of the Expert Committee, will determine the extent to which a member may be involved in the discussion or decision concerning the matter involving the potential conflict of interest.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 9 February 1998:

question.para: With reference to the report in the Age on 28 June 1997 that the Federal Government would continue to exempt the Melbourne Formula One Grand Prix from section 18 of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992:

(1) Was this an accurate report of the Government's intention; if so, was the Government at that time satisfied that failure to specify the event would be likely to result in the event not being held in Australia.

(2) (a) On what date was an application made to the Federal Government by the Australian Grand Prix Corporation for an exemption from section 18 of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992 for the purposes of the proposed event in March 1988; and (b) can a copy of the application be made available.

(3) (a) When will the exemption be granted; (b) what conditions will apply to the exemption and can a copy be made available; (c) will tobacco companies be permitted to use the image of a kangaroo in their advertising at this event; (d) on what basis exactly was the Minister's opinion formed that the event would be lost; (e) whose views were canvassed in forming that opinion; and (f) can copies be provided of relevant material in forming this opinion.
(4) Is the Minister aware that Oxford University will be sponsoring a team in the British Silverstone Grand Prix in place of tobacco advertising.
(5) (a) What evidence is there that alternatives to tobacco advertising revenue are not also available in Australia; and (b) can such evidence by provided.
(6) Is the Minister aware that Belgium has, in the past 12 months, refused to allow tobacco advertising at its Grand Prix.
(7) Has the Government acquainted itself with the latest status of tobacco advertising permissible at such events in other countries; if so, can the data be made available.
(8) Has the Government collected data on the conditions set by other countries which permit to bacco advertising; if so, can the data be made available.

(9) Has the Government collected data on the way in which tobacco advertising at previous events has been used in the print and electronic media during the event and subsequently; if so, can such data be made available.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The report in the Age on 28 June 1997 that the Federal Government would continue to exempt the Melbourne Formula One Grand Prix from section 18 of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992 is not accurate.

Decisions in relation to any future event are made in accordance with the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992 and the Guidelines which were tabled in June 1993. Each decision is made on a case by case basis.

The report also states that seven events are now exempt from the ban. This is also not accurate. An event may have been granted an exemption for 1997, however, an exemption in one year provides no guarantee of an exemption in the following year.

At the time of the report of the Age in June 1997, the Government was satisfied that failure to specify the 1997 event that had been held earlier in the year would have been likely to result in the event not being held in Australia.
(2) (a) The Australian Grand Prix Corporation's application for the March 1998 event was dated 5 November 1997 and received by the Minister for Health and Family Services on 7 November 1997.
(b) A copy of the application cannot be made available as the application was submitted on a confidential basis and contains sensitive commercial information.
(3) (a) An exemption for the 1998 Australian Formula One Grand Prix was granted on 4 February 1998.
(b) The exemption and the conditions which apply to the exemption were published in the Commonwealth of Australia Special Gazette No. S 51, Monday, 9 February 1998. A copy is attached.

(c) The use of the image of a kangaroo in advertising by particular companies is a commercial decision which is not covered by the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992. It is not a matter over which the Minister for Health and Family Services has any control.

(d) As required by the legislation and the Guidelines, the Minister took into account (a) whether the organisation responsible for allocating the event is not located in Australia (b) if other countries are eligible to hold the event, the strength of their claims to do so, and (c) other information the Minister felt relevant in determining the likelihood that the event would not be held in Australia.

Given that the information provided in the application in relation to these matters is commercial-in-confidence, the details cannot be revealed. The Minister was satisfied that the event was an event of international significance which would be lost to Australia if an exemption was not granted.
(e) The Minister took into account all of the material submitted by applicant which included information provided by the overseas promoters.
(f) Copies cannot be provided of relevant material in forming this opinion given that the application and discussion of the contents of the application is commercial-in-confidence.
(4) The Minister was not aware that Oxford University will be sponsoring a team in the British Silverstone Grand Prix in place of tobacco advertising.
(5) In assessing applications under section 18, the Minister requests applicants to provide evidence that they have sought alternative sponsorship.
With respect to the Australian Formula One Grand Prix, sponsorship arrangements are controlled by the international event organisers or promoters, not the local event organiser, the Aust-

ralian Grand Prix Corporation. Any possible availability of an alternative to tobacco advertising revenue does not of itself guarantee that Australia would continue to be granted the right to host a round of the Formula One Championship.
The information provided in applications is submitted in commercial-in-confidence and thus not available.
(6) The Minister is aware that Belgium has, in the past 12 months, refused to allow tobacco advertising at its Grand Prix.
(7) The Government has acquainted itself with the latest status of tobacco advertising permissible at Grands Prix in other countries.

(8) The Government has not collected data on the conditions set at each Grand Prix by each of the countries which hold such events and which permit tobacco advertising, but it has collected data on the type and level of tobacco advertising restrictions in each of these countries. This data can be made available.

(9) The tobacco advertising that has appeared in the print and electronic media during or subsequent to previous Australian Formula One Grands Prix has either been permitted by the exemption applying to the event or has been accidentally or incidentally present during coverage of the event.
